TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: National Film and Sound Archive headquarters accommodation, Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: The current accommodation used by the National Film and Sound Archive to house its administrative and specialist technical facilities is inadequate because it does not satisfy current occupational health and safety standards; because it uses original gallery space for office and technical accommodation, which is inconsistent with the building's heritage significance and limits the space available for public exhibitions; and because it includes demountable buildings which compromise the site's heritage significance and which are inconsistent with the intentions of the national capital plan. These inadequacies were recognised in the Commonwealth government's October 1994 Creative Nation policy statement, which announced that the government would provide the archive with funding to extend its accommodation facilities and to refurbish its heritage listed headquarters building.

PARA.TAB: In response to this initiative, it is proposed to construct a 3,800-square-metre building to the north-west of the existing headquarters building. The building will include office, technical, meeting and amenities areas, plant and services, a loading dock, pedestrian and service access links between the new building and the existing headquarters and associated site works, engineering services and landscaping.

In addition, some modifications will be made to the existing car park. Additional on-site parking will provide for approximately 25 cars and five tourist coaches. The new building will be designed to provide safe, secure and suitable facilities and accommodation for the National Film and Sound Archive and improve access to its collection by television and film makers and by all Australians.

The limit of cost estimate for the project at September 1995 prices is $12.4 million. If parliamentary approval is obtained, construction will commence in April 1996 for the whole works to be completed by mid-June 1997. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 22nd, 23rd and 24th reports of the committee for 1995 relating to the development of 1 Field Hospital, Holsworthy, New South Wales; the development of Ready Reserve (49 Battalion, Royal Queensland Regiment and 6th Brigade Administrative Support Battalion) working accommodation, Enoggera, Queensland; and the provision of living-in accommodation at HMAS Harman, ACT.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The first report I have tabled recommends the construction of a modern purpose-built field hospital for the Australian Army at Holsworthy to replace the existing inadequate medical facilities of 1 Field Hospital at Ingleburn in Sydney's west. The proposed hospital is required to support Australian Defence Force operations during a contingency, in accordance with the defence policy of self-reliance, as outlined in the 1994 defence white paper.

PARA.TAB: The proposed facility will provide health care for regular Defence personnel located in the area known as the Liverpool Military Area, as well as army reserve personnel and visiting overseas military forces. The hospital will consist of a field component, and an Australian support area component which will continue to service those personnel who do not deploy when the field hospital deploys on operations. The facility is based on a 25-bed ward and a 16-bed self-care rehabilitation unit. The estimated cost when referred to the committee was $19.7 million at December 1994 prices.

In common with the defence forces of other developed nations, the Australian Defence Force provides medical and dental treatment to serving members; this is to maintain the highest standards of medical, dental and physical fitness. Such treatment is provided both in the field and in the barracks environment and ensures that members remain fit and available for operations. Field treatment for the Australian Army is provided by field hospitals such as 1 Field Hospital in Sydney and 2 Field Hospital in Brisbane.

During the public hearing a proposal was put by the Southwestern Sydney Area Health Service that Defence should make use of facilities at the Liverpool Hospital. However, while the committee recognises the need for certain medical procedures to be performed at civilian hospitals, the committee agrees with the Department of Defence that operational requirements necessitate 1 Field Hospital possessing a wide range of medical capabilities. These include operating theatres, intensive care, pathology and radiology services.

During its inquiry, earlier this year, into a replacement medical centre at RAAF Richmond the committee expressed concern at the high incidence of sporting injuries requiring treatment. While the committee recognised the need for service personnel to become and remain physically fit, it questioned whether this fitness was being achieved in the most efficient manner. At the Holsworthy hearing the sectional committee was informed by Defence that injuries resulting from either training or sporting activities were of concern to Defence and were currently being investigated.

The committee has recommended that the Department of Defence advise it of the results of the study being undertaken of training and sporting injuries in the Australian Defence Force which require medical treatment.
The second report which I have tabled recommends the construction of functional working accommodation for the ready reserve at Gallipoli Barracks, Enoggera, Queensland at a cost of $21.3 million.

In May 1991 the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) announced the ready reserve program. The ready reserve components were formed in the Australian Defence Force in 1992 as a means of increasing the ADF's capacity to deploy well-trained personnel in shorter time scales than conventional reserves. This implementation has increased the number of infantry battalions within Enoggera from two to three, without the provision of any new facilities.

The success of the ready reserve implementation relies on the ability of 49 Royal Queensland Regiment to be an operationally effective unit. 49 Royal Queensland Regiment occupies facilities dispersed over nine separate locations. The separate locations, lack of functionality, and in some cases inadequate size, detract from unit effectiveness and the effective utilisation of accommodation in Gallipoli Barracks. This also impacts on the morale of unit members as they can see that other battalions are better accommodated than 49 RQR. The unit layout as it now exists leads to inefficiencies in control, administration and training.

Construction of the proposed facilities will redress significant shortfalls existing in accommodation of 49 Royal Queensland Regiment at Enoggera. However, should there be a change in policy in relation to the retention or the role of the ready reserve, the facilities would be adaptable for use by other units.

The committee has always been concerned with energy conservation measures. Therefore, the committee requires the Department of Defence to undertake, as soon as possible, an energy audit to assess the efficiency of the existing energy management system at Enoggera Barracks. The committee further requires the Department of Defence to make available to it the consultants' examination of energy consumption costs for this project.

The third report which I have tabled involves the provision of living-in accommodation at HMAS Harman here in the ACT. This proposal will provide an increase in the current living-in accommodation on the base from 232 personnel to a total of 428. It will replace existing unsuitable and substandard accommodation for 54 personnel. The committee has recommended that this proposal, which will cost $18.3 million, should proceed. It is proposed that construction will commence in January 1996 with completion in late 1997.

A major function of HMAS Harman is to provide accommodation and messing for personnel working on the base and naval personnel serving in the Canberra area. The committee has concluded that there is a lack of suitable available living-in accommodation at HMAS Harman which has resulted in the base having one of the highest allowance costs of any naval establishment. Alternatives examined aimed at reducing allowance costs have indicated that the provision of additional living-in accommodation at HMAS Harman is the most cost-effective solution due to the well developed infrastructure, adequate land, location and lower capital and recurrent costs.

The committee concluded that the location and extent of the proposed development at HMAS Harman conforms with zone planning and will address immediate accommodation, messing and recreational requirements. The report recommends that the Department of Defence undertake a study of the use of HMAS Harman as a possible triservice centre of living-in accommodation for single Defence personnel working in the Canberra area.

The report also canvasses the impact of aircraft noise on the base and the need for the scope of the project to be extended to provide a new formal entrance to the base. It also recommends further study of the practicalities of using grey water to irrigate the playing fields and the landscaping. I commend the reports to the House.

My Uncle Bob served there as a sailor in the 1950s and I think the block he used to live in is still being used.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate that all governments look after their service personnel, and I welcome the approval given by the Public Works Committee for the work that will be carried out at HMAS Harman. TALK.START.PARA: —The Employment Services Amendment Bill 1995 provides an opportunity to look at the government's employment strategy and at what a total disarray and a shocking state of affairs it is in. Every time a bill on employment is introduced in this House, the government continues to make changes. It has no clear strategy for dealing with the problems of unemployment in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Employment Services Act 1994 established the case management system and the Employment Services Regulatory Authority as an independent statutory authority responsible for regulating the case management system. The bill makes machinery changes arising from changed case management arrangements for certain part-time and seasonal workers. It will also streamline certain administrative procedures relating to the CES notification requirements and allow ESRA, the Employment Services Regulatory Authority, to obtain goods and services by using a credit card. I hope they use it wisely, Mr Speaker, because, as you would be well aware, credit cards have created a bit of a problem for the government.

The bill also allows for consequential amendments arising from proposed changes to the Social Security Act 1991 that would amalgamate the jobsearch allowance and the newstart allowance. Here is another change. It would also amend the Social Security Act 1991 to provide for the national convenor of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to delegate his or her powers under the Employment Services Act.

I want particularly to address the House's attention to the job compact, which shows the government's lack of strategy and the disarray and disorder that it is in. Job compact eligibility for certain seasonal and part-time workers is being amended by the bill. The definition of persons eligible for the job compact is being amended to include the requirement that, in addition to having been in receipt of the jobsearch, newstart or youth training allowance for a period of 18 months, a person must have been registered with the CES for a period of 18 months.

On seasonally adjusted figures as at 18 October 1995, long-term unemployment—that is, anyone who has been unemployed for 18 months or more—increased in Australia by 6,600 persons in the last month. That is 6,600 people in one month added to the long-term unemployed, making a total of 237,700 people—almost a quarter of a million people—in the Australian community who are long-term unemployed. Those people have been unemployed for 18 months or more.

The government's strategy is this: you have to be out of work for 18 months in order to get a job for 13 or 26 weeks. After that you can then join the bottom of the queue and become unemployed for 18 months again. I repeat that because the minister at the table, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), is hanging his head in shame—so he should. The government's strategy under the job compact is that you have to be out of work for 18 months, so that you then get a job for 13 or 26 weeks, so that then you can join the bottom of the queue—a queue of 237,700 which becomes 237,701—and become unemployed for 18 months again.

The queue of the long-term unemployed people has blown out in the last month by 6,600. The total unemployment figure for the month is another indictment of the government's disarray on employment strategy. As at 12 October 1995, the number of unemployed people rose by 9,900 to a total of 763,100 unemployed people in Australia. It is disastrous news for Australia that, in just one month, another 9,900 people have been added to the unemployment queue to boost the unemployed figure to 763,100.

The minister at the table would understand this because he does follow Australian Rules football. That figure of 763,100 is eight times the number of people at the Melbourne Cricket Ground for an AFL grand final. Eight times the number of people at the MCG for the AFL grand final in Australia are unemployed. What a disgraceful episode this government has entered into. What you have done is absolutely diabolical.

Minister, if you were going to pursue a strategy, one would have thought you could have come up with something better than the one I have just read out to you—because that is what the job compact does. All that the government's priority and strategy intend to do is to remove people from the unemployment figures without really getting them a job. You take unemployed people off the figures and manipulate the system in whatever way you can in an attempt to reduce the numbers that make up the unemployment statistics. It does not matter if you recategorise those people, change or rename the system or amalgamate jobstart and newstart. All those things purely and simply are being done by the government in order to manipulate the figures and make it appear as though unemployment in this country is lessening.

But those figures really do not tell the full story of unemployment. The latest figures—and I have just read them to the House—of about 763,100 people being without jobs simply do not tell the real story of unemployment. There are many people, in my own area of Bendigo in particular, where the regional unemployment figures have almost doubled just over the last five years. I repeat: those figures have almost doubled just over the past five years.

A lot of the jobs that have been created under some of these schemes, such as the jobs compact and a number of others, are part-time jobs of short duration. All that those jobs do is to take unemployed people off the numbers on the list of unemployed; those people then go on to a short-term part-time job and, of course, the general public then looks at the unemployment figure and it appears as though the government is doing something about it. But the real fact is that the unemployment figures in my area have doubled in the last five years, and in many other parts of Australia there is a similar situation.

But there are many more facets to unemployment. Many people in the community want to work more hours. They are working part time, a few hours through the week, and they do not appear on the unemployment figures. There are many people who are seeking the opportunity to do more work, more hours. But they are unable to find the opportunity to do additional work because of the government's economic problems and its mismanagement of the unemployment strategy. It is quite clear to me that, with 153 jobs lost in Bendigo itself over the past three months, the policies of the Keating government are simply not working and it does not have the strategy in place to deal with the country's level of high unemployment.
The tragedy of youth unemployment is another matter again.

The government should be condemned for its strategy and its economic mismanagement when you see headlines such as `Jobless state's worst' which appeared in the Bendigo Advertiser of Thursday, 21 September 1995. The article below that headline states:
The Bendigo region has the highest youth unemployment rate in Victoria.
According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics the Loddon-Campaspe-Mallee region, of which Bendigo is a part, had a youth unemployment rate of 29.4 per cent in August this year . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is, in August 1995 almost 30 per cent of youth in the Bendigo region were unemployed. That any government could create this problem by its economic mismanagement and then continue to oversee it is a disgrace. The article continues:
An ABS spokesman said the bureau's labour force survey showed there were 5500 youths looking for full-time work in the Loddon-Campaspe-Mallee region in August this year.

Those 5,500 young people have aspirations and ambitions: they want to get out and work; they want to create some employment opportunities for themselves to have long-term security; and they want to develop a career that will stand them in good stead. But the mismanagement of the Australian economy by the Keating government has meant that that region—the Bendigo region in the Loddon-Campaspe-Mallee region—has seen youth unemployment increase up to almost 30 per cent during the August period of this year. So there are 5,500 young people without the opportunity to get a full-time job in that area. That is an absolute disgrace.

PARA.TAB: Even the acting regional manager of the Commonwealth Employment Service said that his department was giving top priority to tackling youth unemployment in the Bendigo region. I know that the CES—and I respect the acting regional manager—are trying hard to do it, but they can only do what is within the government's strategy. They are issued with instructions on how they can handle unemployment and they have to work within those confines. They cannot make policy changes. Those policy changes come direct from the government, and if the government has the wrong policies in place, no matter how hard the Commonwealth Employment Service try to place those young people, they will not be successful.

The acting regional manager—and I will not quote his name—said that four new case managers had been appointed to give assistance to youths and school leavers looking for jobs. He said, `We are aware the problem exists in the community, and we want to see it reduced.' He said that the situation would improve in coming months as 100 jobs would be available through the Landcare employment assistance program. That is 100 jobs to address a problem of 5,500 youths out of work. It is hardly a drop in the bucket. Yet that is about all that is becoming available. Other developments are occurring in the Bendigo area and, hopefully, there will be some jobs as a result of those developments which include a new Big W and a Safeway store which will be opening at the Bendigo marketplace.

I think the problem goes way beyond 100 positions in those sorts of areas. We are looking at a major problem and a major gap in the government strategy, where all they do is continue to change the programs, call them different names, restructure them, and take people on and off the unemployment list in a cold and callous way which really has no regard for the future of young people and their chance of finding a permanent long-term job and a permanent long-term career.

I think that was never highlighted more than when I asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) in the House about youth unemployment problems and how the Keating government had failed Bendigo. I also asked him about his strategy. He did admit that the government had problems with teenage unemployment and that Working Nation was deficient. Here we see another opportunity for the government to bring forward a bill, yet it is fiddling at the edges without really addressing the major problem facing this nation.

Minister Crean also said that a new employment scheme would be introduced before the 1996 election campaign to help unemployed youths. That is really what it is all about. That is precisely what the minister said, that they had put another strategy in place—a new employment scheme—that they would use to fiddle at the edges and try to reduce the numbers on the unemployed list so that they can go to the election in 1996 and say, `Aren't we great fellows? We've got our economic strategy and our employment strategy in place, and we've started to reduce the numbers on the unemployment list. We will be able to go out and hold our heads high in that campaign in 1996.'

The underlying figures are not good. In fact, as I indicated to the House, there are thousands and thousands of people—up to 1 1/2 million—in Australia who want to work more hours. They want to be productive, but the government's strategy and economic management policies do not allow it. These people would be very happy to do some more work. Some of them who are doing only a few hours work per week are looking for the opportunity to make a major contribution to the wellbeing and the economic prospects of this nation. But, under the present structure which deals with unemployment, the government are simply not interested in that at all. What they are interested in is manipulating the unemployment figures to make them look good to the general public.

I refer to the headline in the Bendigo Advertiser on Thursday, 12 October 1995 which reads `Jobs crisis still critical: figures tell sorry story'. This article refers to the total number of unemployed people. It reads:
Bendigo's jobless rate remains extremely high despite record new job creation.

SPEECH.PARA: This `record new job creation' relates to what the government claim to be around 1,000 new jobs. I am still quite interested to find out where those 1,000 jobs have come from, but I can assure the House that they are not long-term jobs. Most of them will be either for 13 weeks or 26 weeks. I refer to the Bendigo jobs figures which were published in the Bendigo Advertiser. The article lists the number of unemployed in the June quarter. In 1990 there were 3,911 people unemployed and in 1994 there were 8,903 people unemployed. In just 4 1/2 years, the figure increased to 8,903, which is double the 1990 figure of 3,911. Regrettably, the jobless rate at the June quarter in 1990 was 6.3 per cent and in 1994 was 14.5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: You can understand the frustration faced by young people in my area who cannot get a full-time permanent job and who cannot find career prospects. The government are not interested in dealing with that problem. They have the wrong economic policies in place. They do not offer unemployed people long-term prospects. They are interested only in reducing the number of people on the unemployment list.

The CES, as I indicated earlier, are desperately trying to help these young people. They have recently appointed four case managers, but those case managers are going to have to try to find jobs for 500 youths. Those four case managers will each have to try to find a job for about 125 young people. That is a huge task in terms of case management. That is precisely what this bill before us does: it deals with the role of case managers and the activities that they will pursue.

Minister, how on earth could you expect someone to case manage 125 people and try to find them jobs when the jobs simply are not there, are extremely difficult to find or are of a short-term nature? This is the situation which exists today. The government have not dealt with unemployment adequately. They do not have the economic policies or the structure in place to deal with what is happening in rural Australia and in many other areas of Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Employment Services Amendment Bill 1995 following the comments of the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), who has been a longstanding advocate for the interests of young unemployed people in his electorate. It is something that I know is very close to his heart. Like him, in my electorate we have a large number of young unemployed people who many would consider, looking at the government's legislative record and its record in government since 1983, to be the forgotten Australians. They are forgotten because not only are their interests ignored by the Australian government but also they are treated in a way which is fraudulent and misleading. They are shuffled from one scheme to another in order to satisfy the government's interest in manipulating the unemployment figures.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would have heard yesterday in question time, amongst the vitriol levelled at members of the opposition by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was an accusation to one of the members of the front bench that he was a ghost. I put it to the government that the real ghosts in Australia are the long-term unemployed, who are effectively being moved from one scheme to another to avoid the inevitable conclusion that the community in many cases has already made, which is that unemployment in Australia is a national disgrace.

It was interesting to hear the comments of a person who at one time was lauded by the Australian government and at another time is being derided by the Australian Prime Minister: media magnate Rupert Murdoch. He commented on the Australian economy. Rupert Murdoch has made what I think are very telling comments at a time when many government members are trying to not only mislead themselves but also, more importantly, defraud the community in trying to convince them that the economy is operating successfully and we are making the best possible use of our natural resources.

Mr Murdoch made a most telling point when he said that the Australian economy is a disgrace. I would have to agree, as many others in the community would, particularly those who are in any way connected with trying to create wealth in this nation, such as those in small, medium or large businesses.

He observed that the economy was a disgrace. I am sure that members of the government, even the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), would agree that Mr Murdoch is an expert on economic developments. He has had a longstanding observer role in relation to Australia, notwithstanding the fact that he has gone to the United States. His other comment, which was of a far more serious nature, was about youth unemployment. In real terms, young people in this country are carrying the burden of up to 35 per cent unemployment.

If one were to look at the real changes between 1983 and 1995, one would find that probably the most disturbing of them is the decline in the standard of living across the community to the key sector of young Australians. Young Australians, particularly those in 1983 who were unable to vote or have any say whatsoever in the election of the Australian government, have been placed in the position where, in order to compensate for the economic mismanagement of the previous 12 years, they are obliged to cop 35 per cent unemployment. In other words, they have suffered a far more serious decline in their standard of living to accommodate the increase in our national debt and the essential decrease in employment opportunities in the Australian economy.

It is probably one of the great tragedies of our time that we have effectively asked young people to cop that burden without giving them the opportunity to have any say in the matter. Many young people who are suffering from unemployment of those proportions are unable to vote; they are not yet old enough to vote. Many long-term unemployed young people were unable to vote at the last federal election. A large proportion of them would certainly not have been in a position to participate in the 1990 federal election.

As a consequence, young people have seen the federal government of Australia squander their opportunities to enjoy what most of us take for granted as part and parcel of the Australian standard of living, Australian life or what has been known colloquially as the Australian dream: the opportunity of employment, of some security, of making career advancements in one's working life, of being able to buy one's own home, of being able to get married and then raise a family in relative economic security and of being able to save and look forward to providing for one's own retirement. In all these cases, young people in particular have the worst possible prospects.

The cover of this week's Bulletin mentions a story about vandalism to people's motor vehicles. It is interesting that the article outlines observations which were made about why young people in particular vandalise the motor vehicles of other people in the community, particularly those that are probably of a little more value, or expensive motor vehicles. Often it is because of jealousy or the anger and frustration of young people who are unable to look forward to or aspire to owning property or things of that value.

We find ourselves in a nation where a significant proportion of our community feel alienated from not only the opportunities that most of us, particularly my generation, have taken for granted but the opportunity of being able to influence the way in which this country is heading. In looking at all the things that we can do for young people as we move towards the next federal election, surely the most important, the most fundamental, is giving them a vision, a prospect, for a future in which they will be able to enjoy what we have had and what many of us have taken for granted over the years.

The Assistant Treasurer, a person who shares an electorate like mine with a large number of young people—particularly between the ages of five to 15 and a large proportion of people between 15 and 24—would know only too well that many of his constituents contact him and his office and deplore the situation, the circumstances, in which their youngsters find themselves today. He and I share the same problems in our electorates because they have very similar demographic make-ups, as he well knows. Yet he, as part of this government, has participated in what is essentially a grand fraud perpetrated on the very people who are least in the position of being able to either detect it or defend themselves against it.

We find ourselves today debating the Employment Services Amendment Bill, in which a number of amendments are being proposed to the Employment Services Act, which was created to provide, as part of the so-called Working Nation document, opportunities for case management of the cases of long-term unemployed people. But, before I debate some of the amendments, I would like to make a couple of observations.

The member for Bendigo observed that the statistical evidence is that the number of long-term unemployed is increasing in this country—a matter of grave concern for all of us involved in public policy making. In the case of my electorate, use of statistics in relation to unemployment has become almost an art form. It has become an art form because the government has been using scheme after scheme to conceal the real unemployed in our nation. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) often has the gall to stand up in question time and brag about how his government and his policies have been responsible for reducing unemployment in Australia.

Coming from these statistics are a number of other side issues. It is interesting to note that in the budget brought down in 1992 the then Minister for Local Government, Mr Simmons, introduced a local capital works program in which around $24 million—it may have been a bit more than that—was divided up between the various local government regions around Australia for use in employment creation programs.

The Assistant Treasurer sitting at the table today well knows that that was a grand plan devised to funnel valuable funds into marginal Labor seats to help the sitting members get re-elected. One of those seats was the city of Canning. So he was the beneficiary of essentially a grossly disproportionate share of that money compared with other areas in Western Australia.

Of course, in my case in the seat of Moore we got nothing, absolutely zilch, out of a program that was designed to create jobs for the long-term unemployed through local government authorities, which in real terms could well have been a quite laudable objective. However, we could see the base nature of the way in which it was devised, the method of operation used to divide that money. We saw, quite clearly, that it was yet another opportunity for the federal government to send taxpayers' funds to help their sitting members get re-elected, which unfortunately they did at the ensuing election.

I might add that the reason this system was seen to have been base and motivated by purely political objectives was that in Moore, despite the fact that there were 8,500 unemployed people, we saw local government in the city of Wanneroo get absolutely nothing—zilch, zero. Yet in Canning, which had fewer unemployed than the city of Stirling, there was about $5 million expended.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is corrupt. And you want an inquiry into it.

—It is fascinating that the Assistant Treasurer intervenes. He well knows—although he smiles and treats it lightheartedly—that in essence this was a grand scheme to pass on taxpayers' money, to get more public funding to help get Labor re-elected in the marginal seats.

PARA.TAB: Let me talk about another example where the statistics that are manipulated by this government are then used to deprive people of funds or resources to which they would otherwise be entitled. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in this case, because of the way in which that local capital works program was organised—notwithstanding the fact that the city of Stirling and the city of Wanneroo virtually had almost identical numbers of unemployed—we found ourselves in the ridiculous situation where the city of Stirling got $7 million because of a slight variation on notional figures, not real figures, and the city of Wanneroo got nothing.

The notional nature of the break-up of these figures is even more ridiculous when you consider that the breakdown of the figures came from the same two DSS centres that were used by people living in the city of Stirling—Mirrabooka and Innaloo. So we have the ridiculous situation where the figures were notional and broken down by the very same places. By a sleight of hand, the city of Stirling—which is in a marginal seat which fortunately fell nonetheless to the Liberal Party, to the current sitting member—got that $7 million, and the people who deserved it, the people of the city of Wanneroo, saw it slip away and not be shared adequately or fairly between them and the people in the city of Stirling.

In my electorate—in fact, throughout the nation—we have a Commonwealth emergency relief program which is based on unemployment levels. We have the quite ludicrous prospect whereby, as these schemes artificially reduce unemployment levels in the various regions and districts around the nation, other schemes, that have been set up by the federal Labor government that essentially are tagged or related to unemployment figures, are suddenly losing money. My electorate and the electorate of the member for Canning share the same demographic features; there is a concentration of families raising children. Because of the sleight of hand used in shuffling people around under these employment schemes, I suddenly find that my electorate is copping a decline in its emergency relief program allocations.

For instance, that means that in Western Australia overall there has been a decrease of almost half a million dollars. These decreases in emergency relief programs impact on real people—people who need assistance, particularly people raising families, raising young Australians. Here we find a cruel twist of fate where the government, anxious to show itself in a better light for its prospects at the next federal election, manipulates unemployment figures. By a sleight of hand it shows an alleged reduction in unemployment figures. It is then able to reduce other benefits and the devotion of resources to the very same people who are nonetheless copping the same or similar levels of unemployment, notwithstanding these so-called employment schemes.

Let us have a look at this particular bill and the consequences of it. I suppose one of the first observations you would have to make about it is that it helped set up the Employment Services Regulatory Authority. TALK.START.PARA: —The Employment Services Amendment Bill 1995 is typical of the government's approach to solving the unemployment problem. It is tinkering around the edges without addressing the root causes of what is a very serious problem for Australia.

PARA.TAB: This bill proposes to amend the Employment Services Act 1994 in four ways: first, it provides for the Commonwealth Employment Service to issue a notice to participants in the case management scheme only when they are required to come in for a referral interview; secondly, it will change the job compact eligibility requirements for certain seasonal and part-time workers; thirdly, the bill would enable the Employment Services Regulatory Authority—ESRA—to obtain goods and services on credit by the use of a credit card; and fourthly, the bill makes consequential amendments upon the amalgamation of the jobsearch allowance and the newstart allowance into one allowance type. The bill would also amend the Social Security Act 1994 to provide for the national convenor of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to delegate his or her powers under the Employment Services Act 1994. None of those proposals is earth-shattering or likely to have a major impact.

The operation of the case management scheme was examined by the Auditor-General in Audit Report No. 3 of 1995-96 which was released in September. The report was based on visits to the offices of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, interviews with DEET staff, and a survey of clients using case management. The report was tabled on 21 September and this bill was then introduced on 27 September last.

This bill does not address the recommendations of the Auditor-General's report. Given the nature of the recommendations, this is most unsatisfactory. The Auditor-General found that, given the time and other constraints involved, the implementation of case management has been reasonably well managed. But the Auditor-General also found that 39 per cent of clients were not even aware that there was a return to work plan developed for them. This plan is an essential feature of case management and failure to comply with the plan may result in benefits being suspended.

The Auditor-General also found that 43 per cent of clients were of the opinion that their motivation to find work had not altered due to case management. Consequently, the report made a number of recommendations. One of the major recommendations was that, when contacting clients regarding case management, the purpose of the interview and a contact name and number should be provided. It was also recommended that the purpose, obligations and goals of the agreement be clearly explained to each client. The report recommended that guidelines be improved to ensure that case managers have an indication of the level and extent of services to be provided.

It seems to me that it would have been worth while for the government to examine the Auditor-General's report and to delay the introduction of this bill to allow it to incorporate its response to the report into the bill. That would at least have been some attempt to address what are recognised by an independent body to be defects in the government's case management system.

There are several substantial aspects of the unemployment problem that require a serious, intelligent and caring approach by a government determined to reduce the numbers of those out of work. This government has not shown that it is capable of delivering any such solution. This is particularly disturbing to Australians because one of the most serious aspects of unemployment is the very high rate of youth unemployment. And most shamefully, instead of trying to solve the problem of youth unemployment, the government has been trying to hide the extent of the problem by stopping the publication of regional youth unemployment figures and by redefining youth unemployment away.

Just two months ago DEET stopped publishing the regional youth unemployment figures. The most recent of these figures show teenage full-time unemployment at 21.5 per cent in south-west Perth, 27.7 per cent in central Perth, 18.1 per cent in north Perth and 22.2 per cent in regional Western Australia outside the lower west of the state. These figures mean that about one in four young people in Western Australia who are seeking work are unable to find it.

In the 12 months to August 1995 there was an increase of almost 10 per cent in the number of teenage males looking for full-time work. The failure of the government's so-called Working Nation program is its failure to help young people obtain work. The target for the jobstart program was undershot by 90,000 places last year. This was a failure which had a direct impact on young people. As further evidence of the government's failure, apprenticeships and traineeships as a proportion of the work force are at their lowest for 30 years. One can only speculate as to what the impact of that will be on the ability to provide a skilled work force in future years.

The coalition takes no joy in these depressing results. Our aim is to see young people who are seeking work find satisfactory jobs that will last and that will provide them with a valued place in the work force. This government is offering nothing of substance to the young unemployed. It perhaps can offer some place in the labour market program, but it is not offering enough genuine jobs. Unemployment, and youth unemployment in particular, is one of the most serious problems facing Australia today. It is devastating for the individuals involved.

Youth unemployment can generate a loss of motivation in the unemployed person and, as a result, threatens to destroy confidence and hope in our society amongst a whole generation. These young people are more likely to suffer loss of self-esteem the longer their inability to find work persists. They are more likely to be victims of violence in the streets and they are more likely to be drawn into drugs and crime. If they are young men, especially young men living in rural areas, they are more likely to commit suicide. While the overall level of suicide in Australia has not increased for decades, the victims of suicide have shifted from amongst the old to amongst the young. While there are many causes of the depression that can lead to suicide, unemployment is a key cause among young men.

The government has tried to solve the youth unemployment problem by redefining it. It has said that an increasingly large proportion of young people are in continuing education or training and that unemployed young people as a proportion of the total age group are a relatively low proportion. This is dissembling. Unemployment among no other age group is defined as a proportion of the age group. It is always defined as a proportion of those in the labour market. This should be the case for young people as well. To do otherwise is to imply that young people do not have the same rights to unemployment as older people and that it is somehow exceptional and unsatisfactory for them to be seeking work.

Young people do want work. While the participation rate is less for teenagers than for older age groups, it is still at 57.1 per cent. In July this year there were more teenagers in the labour force than not. Of those in the labour force, 230,000 were employed full time and 355,000 part time. Many of those employed part time are at school or at a tertiary institution and many of those employed full time are in part-time education or training. The problem is that the demand for paid work among young people is much greater than the supply. This meant that, sadly, in July this year there were 267,300 young people aged between 15 and 24 looking for work and unable to find it. This meant an overall unemployment rate among teenagers of almost 20 per cent. Among those aged 15 to 19 years looking for full-time work, the unemployment rate was 26.5 per cent. Many of these young people seeking work had been unemployed for over a year. The coalition does not accept that there will never be jobs for these young people. We believe that by appropriate policies job opportunities can be provided for these young people.

These young people lacking employment are not limited to those who are untrained or unskilled. Some seeking work have tertiary qualifications in fields in which they are unable to find employment. Even postgraduate qualifications will sometimes not get a young person a job. The unemployment figures themselves do not, of course, reveal the extent of employment of qualified people in jobs for which their qualifications are not required, there being no relevant jobs in the field in which they have obtained the qualifications.

Most jobs in Australia are provided by small and medium sized businesses and it is important that we stimulate the rate of job creation among those businesses. The sorts of jobs which are missing include those in competitive export industries which, for a range of reasons, seem not to have come into existence. There is no mystery about why jobs are not being created. The Australian economy has for years been constricted by badly conceived labour market regulation, by an incredibly complex tax system with very high compliance costs, by a lack of confidence that governments will control inflation, by the lack of an enterprise and export culture, by one of the largest and most costly government enterprise sectors in the Western world and by one of the smallest vocational education and workplace based training sectors in the industrialised world.

The policies needed are those which ensure that smaller businesses have the confidence to invest and expand. The right policies are those which secure a low interest rate environment, which greatly reduce the compliance costs associated with complex taxes such as the fringe benefits tax, which reduce the onerous paperwork burden and excessive regulation and which allow proper flexibility in determining relationships in the workplace. These are policies which a Howard government would introduce as a matter of priority but which have been absent under the Labor government in recent years. Without these sorts of policies, all other policies and programs designed to support the employment of young people will have little impact.

The second essential feature of a successful employment policy for young people is that it must expand opportunities and incentives for on-the-job as well as off-the-job training. Where there is no paid work available to provide a basis for training, the coalition believes that it should be acceptable for an unemployed person to use any voluntary or community work in which they are engaged as part of their satisfaction of the activity test. This sort of work is beneficial to the community and to the individual. It provides the unemployed person with job skills and contacts and helps foster self-esteem.

In addition, training programs could be improved by making them more local. I know from talking to concerned people in my own electorate that there is a lot of goodwill at the community and regional levels to address the problem of unemployment among young people. In response to the problems young unemployed people are facing, there have been many creative and innovative schemes developed in communities and by agencies in recent years. Unfortunately, many of these have been stifled because they do not comply with DEET guidelines for Commonwealth funding.

The coalition will establish a community employment program with structures which will give much more independence and authority to communities and regions to ensure that effective programs are funded. This means that guidelines should be flexible. The rigid age requirements for some existing programs have often meant that help has been denied to young people who could benefit from it. The coalition will place more weight on getting young people into jobs at the end of training programs, in contrast with the Labor government's focus on getting people off the unemployment statistics and into training programs.

Last weekend the Deputy Prime Minister, the absconding member for Swan (Mr Beazley), launched an advertisement in Western Australia which falsely stated that under a Howard government things would get worse for working people. A part of the intended implication of the advertisement is that under the Howard Liberal government school leavers would be on a youth wage of less than $3.17 an hour. This is simply not true. The coalition is not taking any state based industrial relations reforms as its model, contrary to what the Deputy Prime Minister would like the public to believe. Our policy at the last election to introduce a youth wage has been long abandoned. It will not be revived.

My colleague the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) made it quite clear on a previous occasion that the coalition will not revise the government's training wage traineeship to disadvantage trainees. The training wage has been established under a national award and the coalition has made it clear that the award levels—and we are committed to retaining the award system—will provide the minima in relation to wage levels. This Labor advertisement is simply a Labor lie.

In conclusion, the government must stop sweeping the problem of youth unemployment under the carpet. The government must stop its deceitful scare campaign based on untruths about what a coalition government will do after the next election. This bill does not address the problem—it is an ineffectual tinkering around the edges of the case management system. The government should at the very least respond to the concerns raised by the Auditor-General in his report. Youth unemployment is an area where the coalition would be only too pleased if the government stole our policy ideas. The situation continues to be of tragic proportions and continues to require an immediate response.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am pleased to be able to sum up in this debate and put to rest some of the assertions which have been made by opposition members in the course of it. Before addressing issues raised by the shadow spokesperson, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), I would like to deal with a couple of matters raised by the member for Tangney (Mr Williams). He said towards the conclusion of his speech that the opposition would introduce a new employment program called the community employment program, which would have greater flexibility. I do not know what he means by that. Greater flexibility than what? He clearly does not understand the nature or the range of present labour market programs that are in operation, or the flexibility that is allowed in determining how they operate.

PARA.TAB: I am somewhat surprised at that because what the member should know, if he were on top of the subject, is that a key to the labour market program development over the course of Working Nation thus far has been a dramatic increase in flexibility, substantial improvements in the way in which programs have been delivered and the fact that regional priorities are given great prominence. There are some 61 area consultative committees around Australia which have an increasing role in determining which programs will be run within those regions and how they will operate.

One area that the member ought to be aware of is that of new work opportunities. In fact, in some places, area consultative committees are determining which new work opportunities should be approved and which should not be approved. That is important, because it demonstrates that the opposition does not understand not only the comprehensiveness of our policy programs and the labour market program initiatives but also how they operate or the connection between the various elements of Working Nation.

The opposition does not understand the roles of area consultative committees. It does not understand how the area consultative committees relate to the Commonwealth Employment Service. It does not understand how the area consultative committees have a role in determining which programs will operate and what priorities will be given to programs within the region, particularly in the area of new work opportunities.

The member clearly does not understand the emphasis which has been placed on traineeships by this government and the fact that we are after longer term employment outcomes. He does not understand, nor does he appreciate, I think, the success rate of our programs to date in achieving those objectives. If he did, he would at least acknowledge that we have created some 655,000 new jobs and that there has been quite a dramatic, yet not sufficient, drop in unemployment from 11.2 per cent to 8.7 per cent.

It seems to be beyond the opposition to recognise the elements of Working Nation, how they knit together and what their impact has been on the Australian community. I will come back to the assertions by the member for Tangney a little later on regarding some other aspects of the way in which government policies have been introduced. What he said replicates, in a sense, what has been said by other speakers, particularly the shadow spokesperson, the member for Goldstein.

The theme running through the speeches by the opposition has been largely that case management is not working. In fact, the Working Nation programs, of which case management is a part, have been an outstanding success in their first year of operation. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) stated in the House last week, the message of Working Nation is that this government has a clear strategy for getting unemployment down—a strategy which, as I said, is not understood or appreciated by our opponents. He said that the message is very clear. Our objective is five per cent unemployment by the turn of the decade. We believe we have the policies to do it.

The recently announced enhancements to the Working Nation package clearly demonstrate the flexibility of the program and the ability and willingness of the government to respond to the identified needs of clients. That is another aspect of misunderstanding which is very apparent in the way in which this subject has been addressed by our opponents, and again indicated by the member for Tangney. In the 2 1/2 years since the government was returned to office, we have achieved 655,000 new jobs, and a drop in the unemployment rate from 11.2 per cent to 8.7 per cent. We are committed to this target of five per cent and that is what we will be working towards. The competitive case management system established by the Employment Services Act is now fully in place. In March 1995, EAA let contracts for 102,000 job seekers over 1994-95 and 1995-96.

In 1994-95, around 30,000 job seekers entered case management with private or community sector case managers. The system will now be expanded so that contracted case managers can manage up to 130,000 clients in 1995-96. That is the importance which the government has placed on the competitive model which has been set up by Working Nation, which again is not properly appreciated or understood by the opposition.

The measures in this bill represent machinery changes to the operation of the case management system. In fact, something which I do not believe is properly understood by our opposition is that most of the measures are as a result of policy changes in the social security area. Rather than reflecting adversely on the operation of this case management system, this bill is evidence that the legislation governing the system is working well.

In the Working Nation enhancements which were announced by the minister additional resources are to be provided to ESRA so that contracted case managers can take on the extra 28,000 job seekers. An extra 200 staff will be provided to the CES to enhance service delivery to job seekers. The member for Goldstein stated that contracted case managers consider that they are getting the hard cases. If he understood the legislation—indeed, if anyone in the opposition understood the legislation, they might enlighten the member for Goldstein; they clearly do not understand it, as evidenced by their contributions to this debate—he would realise that the primary factor determining which job seekers go to which case managers is the job seeker's choice. That is, they decide if they want to go to Employment Assistance Australia or to a contracted case manager.

The member for Goldstein's assertions are also not supported by the data which show that Employment Assistance Australia case managers and contracted case managers have the same proportion of harder to place job seekers. The member for Goldstein also claimed that the government was counting people who received the notification letter we are removing through this bill as being in case management to `bump up the numbers'. This of course is incorrect. Job seekers are not counted as being in case management until they are referred to a case management organisation.

The member for Goldstein also commented on the size of the case loads of some case managers. Since case management was first introduced in 1994, the department has been closely monitoring case loads being carried out by case managers to ensure that expected levels of outcomes are being achieved and that workload levels of case managers are in fact reasonable. In the case of Employment Assistance Australia, EAA, rather than stipulate a case load maximum, it is our policy that case loads for individual case managers will be dependent upon a number of factors, including the skills and experience of the case manager, client characteristics, the state of the local labour market and the training and educational opportunities available. For example, a case manager with a high proportion of his or her clients in long-term English as a second language courses will be able to handle a larger case load than a case manager with job seekers actively looking for work. In fact, Employment Assistance Australia has been a very successful innovation.

In the case of contracted case managers, ESRA sought to limit case load sizes during the filling of case loads. Recently, ESRA has decided to lift case load limits in recognition of the changing composition of case loads. The average case load size was 97 at the end of September 1995.

The member for Goldstein also spoke about the ANAO efficiency audit of case management, which was again referred to by the member for Tangney. There are a number of things I want to make clear. Firstly, this was not an audit of the current case management arrangements announced in Working Nation. It was an audit of the old case management arrangements introduced under newstart in March 1994 during an early developmental and implementation phase. The Working Nation case management arrangements commenced in February 1995 following the passing of the Employment Services Act 1994. So I do not quite know what the currency is in having a debate developed by the opposition about an audit which has nothing to do with the present status of case management in Australia.

Let me give you an example of how the audit lacks relevance to the current case management system. The member for Goldstein quoted survey results from the ANAO report. What the member for Goldstein did not mention was that the survey does not appear to consider employment as a key objective of case management or to evaluate case management against outcomes achieved for job seekers, assumes that a job seeker's awareness of the CES process and associated administrative detail reflects the quality and success of the service provided and asked clients about introductory case management procedures and arrangements which no longer exist.

In any event, the ANAO audit states that the overall implementation of case management was well managed. The report identifies a number of significant achievements made under case management—something not acknowledged, of course, by our opponents. It recognises that a case management program was put into place in the time frame required and that clients were aware of their responsibilities and were satisfied with the type and frequency of the contact they had had with the CES. The ANAO noted a number of good strategies and practices that assisted in achieving case management outcomes.

Secondly, the ANAO ignored DEET's advice to delay the audit until the Working Nation case management arrangements were established. Instead, it chose to audit a system, which was constantly evolving, three months into a 12-month process. So is it any wonder, if the opposition believe that the debate they are now pursuing has any legs, that it has not because, clearly, we have something which judged the system very early in its development and not nearly enough thought was given to what would happen over 12 months and what the status would be today.

From the outset, case management was enhanced progressively to improve its effectiveness and efficiency, to accommodate Working Nation changes, and to prepare for further substantial development under statutory case management, which was introduced in February of 1995. Unsurprisingly, because the auditors were aware of the developments taking place as the case management system was implemented, all of ANAO's recommendations reflect the department's operating policies and arrangements. Clearly, either that is not understood by the opposition or they have chosen to ignore it.

Case management provides a valuable and effective service to unemployed Australians. The case management system has been continually enhanced to address dynamic operational conditions and aims to provide the best possible service and outcomes for clients. Despite what the member for Goldstein would have you believe, the government will continue, through appropriate targeting of its labour market programs, to work towards reducing the unemployment rate to the five per cent target it has set for the end of the decade.

It is clear that the opposition has no strategy for tackling unemployment, short of leaving it to the marketplace. We did hear a little gem from the member for Tangney about the community employment program, unexplained—

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfinanced.

—Yes, unfinanced and certainly unexplained. We heard the shadow Treasurer (Mr Costello) on a previous occasion saying that one of the areas they would seek to target for cutbacks in expenditure would be Working Nation. Yet against the member for Goldstein, bleating about the supposed failures of the case management system we are incorporating, arguing that we are not getting effective employment outcomes, we have a record of 655,000 jobs since this government was last elected—not a bad result but something which is not acknowledged positively by our opponents.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, without a coherent policy base, without any policy substance, we have the shadow spokesman for Treasury matters saying that this is an area that they would cut into. Now, as a result of its implementation, we are tuning it up. Yet we have the opposition in here this afternoon bleating about the tuning up process, making direct aspersions about that process, concentrating on an ANAO report which was done three months into a 12-month development phase and which is clearly out of date.

I do not know where the opposition are coming from, or who is advising the shadow minister or his colleagues, but they clearly do not understand Working Nation. They have no policy proposals which they can put to the Australian community to compete with Working Nation. All we have from them are exasperated comments about the way this government is doing its job. We have nothing clear, nothing concrete. There are implicit and quite direct contradictions between comments of the shadow Treasury spokesman, talking about cuts in Working Nation expenditure, and comments by the shadow minister and his colleagues who spoke in this debate about how they would change things—changes which are as yet unfunded.

One would ask them: if you do have a policy, could you please tell us what it is? If you do not have a policy, at least be constructively critical about what the government is doing. There would be no tolerance of the concerns of young Australians or those in need which have been expressed by this government through Working Nation. There would be none of the flexibility that the government has put into its arrangements for the delivery of its labour market services. There would be no regional initiatives of the type this government has put in place through Working Nation's area consultative committee structure.

We have done a great deal to address the needs of unemployed Australians. We have heard the opposition come in here and debate this bill—which, as I said, is really a machinery bill—and use it as a vehicle to try to demonstrate to the Australian community that we are not doing what we said we would do in Working Nation, which is clearly wrong.

I believe that the opposition have given up on the issue of unemployment and they do not have any coherent policy framework. If they did have, they would tell us what it is. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said on a number of occasions, and as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has constantly said, `If you have a policy, let us have it.' If you have some coherent framework for addressing the needs of unemployed Australians, let us see it. If you had something you wanted to tell the electorate about—what you will do to help them get back to work, what you will do in the case of providing traineeships, training programs and vocational training and addressing the needs of young unemployed and those professional people who are out of work—you would tell us what it is.

But, of course, you have not, because you do not have a policy framework. This government will not give up on Working Nation or its objectives. The enhancements announced last week provide the strategy by which the government will achieve its aims on behalf of the unemployed people of this country—much to the chagrin of our opponents.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION (TRANSFER OF ASSETS AND ABOLITION) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 27 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Transfer of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1995 will provide legislative authority for measures that will assist in giving effect to the government's decision to restructure the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. It will also provide for the abolition of related legislation, namely the Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965 and the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Act 1990.

PARA.TAB: The restructuring, or corporatisation, of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was announced in the 1995-96 budget. It is designed to provide the corporation with greater freedom to operate on a strict commercial basis and, as such, to put it on a more comparable footing vis-a-vis its competitors. The decision to follow this approach reflects the same considerations that had earlier influenced the government to attempt to sell the corporation, namely that the prevailing conditions in the mortgage insurance and finance industries now differ considerably compared with when the corporation was set up.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was established as a statutory authority 30 years ago to meet a structural deficiency in the highly regulated financial environment which existed at that time. Its primary charter was to help low income earners with small deposits to obtain housing finance; financial institutions tended to allocate their then scarce housing funds on a least-risk basis.

Since those days, a competitive private sector mortgage insurance industry has emerged in Australia. Together with the finance industry reforms introduced by this government, this has removed the old structural deficiency in the housing finance market. With these improvements in access to housing finance, the objective of the government has been to maintain and enhance these achievements by ensuring that there is an efficient, diverse and competitive mortgage insurance market. The decision a number of years ago to attempt to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation reflected the view that the continued involvement of a statutory authority in the industry was not consistent with this objective. However, efforts to sell the corporation have not proceeded since it has become clear that the sale was not going to produce a satisfactory result.

As a consequence, the government has considered alternative approaches. It commissioned the task force on asset sales financial advisers, Baring Brothers Burrows & Co. Ltd, to undertake a complete review of the sale process and the corporation's position in the market. They concluded, among other things, that the corporation enjoyed a number of advantages over its private sector competitors arising from its statutory authority status, including the guarantee of its liabilities, and from the fact that it is not subject to the supervision of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, ISC.

As these benefits, which put the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation on a different basis to its competitors, would not be available to any potential purchasers, it was difficult for them to establish the nature and size of the business that would exist post-sale and, so, to put a value on the corporation.

The corporatisation arrangements that the government now proposes represent a significant move in addressing these concerns. A new company will be established under the Corporations Law and will be subject to the regulatory requirements of the ISC, as well as those of the states and territories. The new company will be fully capitalised in line with the requirements of the ISC, drawing on part of the present capital and reserves of the corporation.

The existing Commonwealth guarantee will be removed as far as borrowings by the corporation are concerned. However, the Commonwealth guarantee for non-borrowing liabilities has been retained, at least for the moment, to minimise any uncertainty in the mortgage insurance industry that might arise as a consequence of the restructuring of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, given its prominent position in the market. Furthermore, to enable the company to attain the minimum credit rating required for mortgage insurers by state legislation without retaining that guarantee, it would be necessary for the Commonwealth to commit significant additional capital resources to the corporation over and above what is already proposed.

However, in setting a target rate of return for the company, account will be taken of any advantage the retention of the guarantee may accord it. With the removal of the guarantee on borrowing, there is no longer a need for a specific legislative provision as the Treasurer has the powers under the constitution to guarantee liabilities of a non-borrowing nature.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will cease writing business on the day before the new company comes into operation. The insurance policies of the corporation entered into prior to and including that date, which we might refer to as the `old book', will become the direct responsibility of the Commonwealth. In exchange for accepting these liabilities, the Commonwealth will receive the balance of the corporation's capital and reserves. On the budget estimates, the level of funds likely to be transferred to consolidated revenue is expected to be in excess of $100 million.

The new Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will be contracted by the Commonwealth to administer the unexpired portion of all insurance obligations contained in the old book. Funds will be set aside by the Commonwealth in a special account to be established by this new company and will be replenished as and when necessary to meet claims against these insurance contracts.

The transfer of the old book to the Commonwealth along these lines is consistent with the arrangements that would have been put in place had the sale of the corporation proceeded in 1991. Separation of the old book will, in particular, enable the new company's performance to be judged independently of the corporation's previous operations.
The bill currently before the House is designed to assist in giving effect to the arrangements that I have just outlined. It includes the following:

SPEECH.PARA: provision to the Treasurer of the necessary powers to direct the transfer of assets and liabilities in whatever way is considered appropriate to give effect to the abovementioned objectives;

authority for the Treasurer to enter into an agreement with the new company which would cover the terms under which existing insurance contracts would be managed, as well as the means by which payments for claims arising from these contracts could be made. the transfer of staff of the corporation to the new company, as well as the transfer of all current rights enjoyed by those staff with respect to such matters as long service leave, superannuation, maternity leave and Comcare. It is not intended that the interests of the staff should in any way be adversely affected by this corporatisation exercise;
provision to exempt from taxation transactions involving such matters as the transfer of assets that would not have arisen apart from the corporatisation exercise; and

finally, the winding up of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation and the repeal of all relevant legislation relating to the corporation. After being audited by the audit office, they will be tabled in the parliament in due course.

PARA.TAB: The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Transfer of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1995, as outlined by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) in his second reading speech, is designed to facilitate the restructure of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. To this end, the provisions of the bill will see the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation take the form I will outline. The housing loans insurance company will be reconstituted as a new government owned company established under the Corporations Law and subject to regulation by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. As is presently the case, the new company's non-borrowing liabilities will be government guaranteed.

The new company will be fully capitalised in line with the requirements of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The corporation's existing portfolio of insurance policies will, at the time of its restructure, become the responsibility of the Commonwealth, in exchange for which the Commonwealth will receive the corporation's capital and reserves. The new company which replaces the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will be contracted to manage the `run-off' of the existing portfolio of insurance policies, and claims arising from the existing portfolio will be met from future budget outlays.
