The government's decision to restructure or corporatise the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation as outlined in the 1995-96 budget is based on the fact that the conditions that prevail in the mortgage insurance and finance industries are dramatically different from when the corporation was initially set up. As members will be aware, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was established as a statutory authority under the Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965 and has been operating for approximately 30 years. The corporation ensures lenders against losses on loans secured by mortgages, principally in terms of housing loans. However, in more recent years it has grown to encompass secured loans for the purchase, construction or refinancing of non-residential buildings as well.

The role of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, or, for that matter, any mortgage insurance corporation, is quite often misunderstood, I believe, by honourable members. I can recall that at one stage the HLIC was the only player in the field. Of course, since then other private players have come into the market. I think one of the first ones was Morgan Guaranty, which came in some years ago.

I remember from my involvement with the banking industry the reasons why banks took out particularly mortgage insurance. It was really aimed at covering the gap where they lent substantial amounts of money against a property and they did not have enough margin from their own security in the loan to give them absolute protection. Of course, lenders always wanted to make sure they were well protected. I suggest lenders do not sustain much loss in terms of the housing industry.

It is important to make the point that mortgage insurers were protecting only lenders and certainly not the purchasers of properties. If someone defaulted on their loan and it was necessary for a lender to take advantage of their insurance, it would cover only the gap between what the bank or lender would get from the sale of the property and the amount of the loan.

For instance, if they sold a property for $100,000 and the loan was for $110,000, they would only have to call on the insurance company for the difference of $10,000. So it is often suggested that it was actually protecting the purchasers or the owners of the homes. It certainly was not. It was protecting the lender, and it still does today.

Let me come back to some of the changes over the years in the HLIC. In 1985 amendments to the act empowered the corporation to insure approved dealers in the secondary mortgage market against losses on mortgage loans directly or indirectly relating to instruments to be traded in the market. Complementing the 1985 amendments, the government in 1987 altered the act to empower the corporation to enter into reinsurance contracts with lenders or subsidiary companies of lenders.

Today, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is the largest mortgage insurer in Australia and operates in a highly competitive mortgage insurance marketplace. Indeed, the last annual report of the corporation, as at 30 June 1994, reveals that total assets of the corporation stood at $217.7 million, the total number of loans insured stood at a record 94,694 and underwriting profits had reached $17.1 million.

In this context, there can be little doubt that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation has achieved its primary charter of helping low income earners with small deposits to obtain housing finance by providing security for mortgage lenders against the possibility of default, as I highlighted a moment ago. That was the purpose of it: to make it more attractive for all lenders to actually lend at no risk to themselves. The risk was the insurance premium, and the premium was paid by the home owner.

Indeed, the structural deficiencies in the highly regulated financial environment of the 1960s have long since evaporated and it is now time that we place the corporation on a more comparable footing with its competitors and ensure that it has more freedom to act through operations on a strict commercial basis. This in turn will lead to greater efficiency and diversity in the mortgage insurance industry and subsequently the housing industry in the longer term.

That is important now that the HLIC will be able to compete effectively with the other players in the market. This is often the case where the government has set up organisations like the HLIC in the marketplace in which there is no private sector involvement. Now the private sector is picking up the initiative because they can probably see that it is not such a bad business after all. They can come in there and see what has actually happened. So the HLIC can now be very much an effective competitor.

banks refused to lend to borrowers who did not have a record of saving with them, and refused to lend to borrowers who could not offer generous security against their loans. This made it harder for the lower income groups to compete for housing finance against the middle income groups, and forced them to seek out housing finance through alternative and more costly forms of finance.

The member for Higgins was quite clearly contradicting the previous coalition government's attitudes. Perhaps Mr Howard should take some advice from Mr Costello on some of these things, although I am not sure that would be a good idea. We will leave that to them to sort out.

PARA.TAB: It is quite unbelievable, in the light of his previous record, that the opposition leader would have the gall to actually stand in front of the Australian people with rubbery mortgage repayment figures and expect them to believe him. We need to remind the Australian people not to be hoodwinked by the Leader of the Opposition in this way, because his record speaks for itself. It is a disgraceful record and it is something that he should hang his head in shame for. He should apologise to the nation, along with his colleagues.

His pathetic attempts to mislead the Australian people are quickly put into perspective when you logically assess the situation and realise that for the most part loan repayments have risen only in relative terms between 1983 and 1995. You have to consider the fact that average weekly earnings have changed over that period. You have to put all this in context. Every opportunity they have, the opposition quote out of context.

You need to take into consideration the increase in average weekly earnings and the fact that there is now a greater opportunity for young people particularly to have two incomes and to make big cash payments in the early part of housing loans. There is much more flexibility in housing loans. Years ago banks told people what their repayments would be and there was no flexibility whatsoever. There is now much more flexibility in the housing market and much more opportunity for young people to get into their own homes.

Of course, the prices are much more competitive. The price of borrowing is also more competitive. Earlier I referred to the member for Higgins who said that people had to have a track record with the banks. They had to be longstanding customers who had saved all their money with the bank over a given period. There were all sorts of requirements for people to qualify, before they got through the door in the first place to see the bank manager to see whether the bank would even consider lending them any money. Those bad old days have gone. There has been a real revolution in the housing market. I could continue for some time in that vein but perhaps I had better not as my time is just about at an end.

This legislation gives us the opportunity to debate the requirements of mortgage insurance in the housing loan sector. I am sure that the move that the government has made through the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will ensure the continuation of the HLIC as an effective player in the market. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one outstanding fact about mortgage insurance—which is what we are talking about in this debate on the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Transfer of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1995—and that is that, as far as the ordinary home owner is concerned, the ordinary person who has to get a mortgage, it is a rip-off and a rort. They do not understand, when they are having to pay out so many hundreds of dollars, that it is not insurance for them; it is insurance for the lender—for the banks and insurance companies.

PARA.TAB: That is an absolute disgrace because you have a situation where somebody borrows money to buy a house and they think that, because they pay the insurance premium, they are being protected. Not on your nelly! No way! If you fall behind—if you lose your job and fall on hard times and cannot pay—the lenders take the house from you and flog it for whatever they can get for it. Mortgage insurance is not there to protect your mortgage; it is there to protect the difference between what is owed on the house and what the insurance company gets when it flogs it off at sale. The insurance companies do not care about the borrowers.

If you were a battler, an ordinary Australian family member, and you fell on hard times, if you had paid $900 or $1,200 in mortgage insurance you would think you would get something out of it—that you would get some protection. The reality is that when that happens there is no concern for ordinary families. They are left in the lurch. They end up without a house, with nothing. I am very angry about that.

I say to my friend the member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott)—who is living in the past, talking about former coalition policies—not to forget the Whitlam years. I had a mortgage then and I had mortgage insurance. Thank God, I did not have to lose my house but I know how my interest rates went up and how the payments went up.

So if we want to talk about the past we can talk about Whitlam as well, but we need to be concerned with the present day and with the future. We could go on living in the past forever if you liked but we need to learn from it, not live in it. These days, with an election looming, all that my friends on the other side can do is bring up anecdotes about what happened in the past. People are far more concerned about what is happening now.

I want to repeat that mortgage insurance, as far as the ordinary battling home owner is concerned, is a rip-off and a rort. Mortgage insurance covers lenders against the loss of principal, interest and other costs resulting from default by borrowers where the subsequent sale of a property fails to cover the outstanding debt. The Commonwealth owned Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is the main provider of mortgage insurance.

While HLIC insurance cover protects the lender and involves a contract between the lender and HLIC, it is standard practice for lenders to charge the borrowers the full cost of mortgage insurance. They charge $900 as a one time premium for a $100,000 first mortgage loan with a loan to valuation ratio of 85 per cent. On a 90 per cent loan to valuation ratio the premium would be $1,200.

I know from personal experience that when you are buying a home you are strapped—you do not have lots of spare cash floating around but you desperately want to get your own home—but at the very last minute you find you have to provide another $900 or $1,200 to provide insurance for the lender. If the lender is so uncertain of your ability to repay, they should not be lending to you, or, if they want to protect themselves, they should take out the insurance and they should pay for it.

In 1993-94 there were 325 claims under this scheme, totalling $6.7 million—an average of $20,500. But the number of loans enforced in 1993-94 was 94,694. Over 94,500 loans were enforced and they claimed on 325. The claims totalled $6.7 million, but the premiums written amounted to $57.7 million. An enormous amount of money is going into the premiums, but very few claims are being made.

I believe very definitely that we have to try to restructure the whole concept of mortgage insurance. I know the government wants to sell off the HLIC. It is making its third attempt now. It tried once in 1990, again in 1993 and it is having another go at it. I point out, too, that the government is going to milk $100 million from the existing HLIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never.

—The Assistant Treasurer says `Never'. Let him deny it and tell us about it. You say you are not going to take $100 million out of it? Well, it is there in black and white; you can say `never' if you like.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the most important point about this. My concern is for the ordinary Australians, the families who live in my electorate—at Nambucca Heads, Toormina, Bayldon, South West Rocks or up the Macleay Valley. They want to be part of the Australian dream. They want to own their own homes, and, quite frankly, I believe they have a right to own their own homes. But they need to be able to get a loan without having to find another $900 or $1,200 for insurance premiums, which is rightly the responsibility of the lender. It is totally inappropriate that ordinary people should be put into the situation of having to find that extra money. As I said, in 1993-94 there were only 325 claims, and the income was significantly higher.

When you look at the report of the HLIC, you see that all but a handful of the loans insured were for home ownership. It has now insured more than one million mortgages since it has been going. I believe that most of those premiums should have been paid by the insurers. In 1993-94 it had earned premiums of $34.8 million.

It is worth noting, too, the number of executive employees earning significant incomes. In 1993 one executive earned between $100,000 and $110,000 and another earned between $120,000 and $130,000. In 1994, the number had grown to five. The HLIC has a total executive pay package of $539,000. The year before it was $222,000. It is outstanding that a Commonwealth corporation that is there purely to administer mortgage insurance needs to increase its number of highly paid executives by 2 1/2 times in one year.

It is also very interesting that it has one executive earning in excess of a quarter of a million—$260,000—when ordinary battlers are having to fork out the $900 or $1,200, which they are having great difficulty in finding, to insure the mortgage. It is totally inappropriate. It is also very interesting that the full-time member of the corporation—who is not an employee as such, I believe—earns $128,000. So there is an enormous outlay of taxpayers' money for the salaries of the people administering this.

Yet the workers, the battlers, are being hit for $900 or $1,200 to pay mortgage insurance, which I believe should be paid by the lending authorities. They are the ones getting the protection. There is absolutely nothing in it for the home owners. If they default on their payments, if they cannot pay the interest or if they cannot pay the capital, they lose their homes—they lose the lot—and the only ones to benefit are the lending authorities; and they should be paying the premiums.

PARA.TAB: Recently we had another article, referred to yesterday in question time, as the member for Flinders mentioned, from the Business Review Weekly published last Friday. In this, the shadow Treasurer is quoted as wanting to address the issue of vertical fiscal imbalance, which is, of course, the issue that the Commonwealth government raises much more than it actually spends and the states raise in taxation rather less than they actually spend and the Commonwealth makes up the difference to the states by making payments to them.

The issue with vertical fiscal imbalance is supposed to be that there is a problem involved in that, such that the states do not act responsibly in their expenditure if they do not raise the revenue they expend so, therefore, we should have a system of fiscal balance as between the federal and state governments, both of them spending effectively what they raise in tax revenue.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said in this article that this issue of vertical fiscal imbalance was `an important issue that has to be addressed'. He is also quoted as saying that it is `something we will be dealing with in our first term (of government)'. He goes on to say that the coalition will work to end vertical fiscal imbalance. He is described as saying that he has had discussions with all the state conservative governments and oppositions on the issues and they all support the idea of ending vertical fiscal imbalance. The article also quotes him as saying:

We see that there is a whole series of direct statements of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, or statements attributed to him, about the need to address this issue and the importance of doing so. What the article then goes on to say, having talked about the Deputy Leader of the Opposition saying that he is willing to discuss these proposals with the state leaders and opposition leaders from their own party, is:

PARA.TAB: One proposal being discussed would have 15 percentage points of marginal income tax rates paid directly to the states, rather than the Commonwealth. Once the states had this power, they could raise or lower the rates, allowing them to abolish some of the . . . taxes.

ANSWER.PARA: If this were to happen—this is clearly something that is being discussed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition with his state counterparts—then clearly that would have some very substantial ramifications indeed. It would mean that the states would have responsibility for 16 per cent of income tax. The Commonwealth would remove itself from that and the states could then vary that amount depending on how they wanted to raise the money. But what it would mean is that, at 16 per cent, you would have vastly different outcomes per state from what you get now because of the allocations that are made through the grants commission redistributing the amounts to the states on the basis of need, and through the specific purpose payments. All of those things would go. It would all be raised by the states. There would be no payment from the Commonwealth to the states.

PARA.TAB: That would mean that, with this same amount of money involved, the allocation to the states would have been that New South Wales and Victoria would be better off by over $1 billion each—so they would be okay—but Queensland and South Australia would lose over $700 million each, Western Australia would lose $220 million, Tasmania would lose $360 million and the Northern Territory would lose $830 million.

The states would be in the position where they would have these totally different outcomes than they now have through the current system. If they were to try to make up the difference, then New South Wales and Victoria could cut their rates by 2.6 per cent and 2.9 per cent respectively. So, in the case of New South Wales, instead of a 16 per cent rate they could lower that to 13.4 per cent and the ACT could cut its rate by four per cent, but all the other states and territories would have to increase their taxes.

Queensland would have to raise their taxation rate by 2.9 per cent to 18.9 per cent. So everyone in Queensland would be paying an additional 2.9 per cent of their income in tax. In Western Australia it would go up to 17.4 per cent. They would all be paying an additional 1.4 per cent in Western Australia.

In South Australia the taxation rate would go up to 22 per cent. They would all be paying an additional six per cent. In Tasmania it would have to go up to 25.9 per cent. They would all be paying an additional 10 per cent. In the Northern Territory the position becomes quite ridiculous. They would have to be paying an additional 58.3 per cent, taking the total rate up to 74.3 per cent. That is before the rest of the federal income tax applies.

The top tax rate in the Northern Territory would then be over 100 per cent, 106.8 per cent—a ridiculous and absurd outcome, but that is the logic of what is being proposed in this article in the BRW, stemming from the discussions the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has had directly with BRW and with his state party counterparts. You have, therefore, a totally unacceptable outcome in terms of the impact that would have on the states—quite clearly, much higher taxes in most parts of the country and absurdly higher taxes in the Northern Territory and even in Tasmania. So what we have is a ludicrous proposition.

If it is not going to be a matter of changing tax rates—and since this article came out the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has said that he is not going to change any tax rates—he still has all those quotes in the BRW about vertical fiscal imbalance. So did he make them or didn't he? If he did make those statements—and he is not denying that he did—and he is not going to address this through the tax side, he would have to address it through the expenditure side. In other words, he would have to take over, holus bolus, large segments of what is now state government activity and tack it on to the federal budget so that there would not be a vertical fiscal imbalance.

You can have it only one of two ways. You can do it either on the tax side, which you now say you rule out, or you can do it on the expenditure side, which means the federal government takes over reams of what is currently state government activity. It would mean that something around 36 per cent of state government expenditures would have to come on to the federal government books. That would have varying outcomes state by state.

What we have from the opposition is, again, a totally ill-thought-out set of ideas, half-baked proposals. The opposition throws around the fixed share, not realising it will cost $2.8 billion, which makes a mockery of its proposal to cut back the budget outcome or increase the surplus, whatever. Again, the opposition is just wandering through the issue of vertical fiscal imbalance, absolutely without any thought, and putting forward a proposal that would have either on the income tax side or on the expenditure side a ridiculous and absurd outcome.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen claims that radical labour market deregulation will lead to significant increases in productivity and real wages? What is the government's response to those claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the member for Reid, I have seen claims from the Leader of the Opposition that the radical changes that he proposes to make to the Australian labour market would boost productivity and that that would be the basis for rapidly increasing real wages. He said that in this House as recently as yesterday.

PARA.TAB: We know that the Leader of the Opposition is a fan of the New Zealand changes. As he indicated earlier this year, he clearly saw the New Zealand National Party's labour market agenda as the prototype for his own agenda. He said in July:

ANSWER.PARA: Our proposals are not a mirror image of the New Zealand proposals, but they are in the same category, they are of the same type.
So that is something we have got clear. Basically, the New Zealand model is not exactly what he is proposing, but it is the same sort of thing.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at what has happened in the labour market in New Zealand over the last five years in terms of the kind of deregulation that they have had to see what it would be like under a John Howard government. They brought in their employment contracts act in the middle of 1991, which essentially put into place a system of widespread individual contracts. You can still have enterprise bargains, but individual contracts are very much promoted.

It did not take very long before the New Zealand workers found out what that system meant. Just one year after the act was introduced, a survey was undertaken by the Heylen Research Centre for the New Zealand Department of Labour. It showed that many New Zealand workers on new contracts suffered a significant loss of conditions. For instance, the survey showed that overtime rates had been reduced or abolished in 42 per cent of enterprises and raised in only seven per cent; that weekend rates had been cut in 43 per cent of cases and raised in three per cent; that special allowances were cut in 29 per cent and increased in 12 per cent; that sick leave was reduced in 15 per cent and raised in six per cent; that long service leave was cut in 16 per cent and raised in four per cent; and that the ability to accumulate leave was reduced in 29 per cent and improved in two per cent. There is not much doubt what the impact of the system was in terms of all of these areas of conditions of employment. It meant on a wide scale the loss of conditions of employment.

This business of saying, `Okay, you've now got this individual contract; you can go off and negotiate on an equal basis with an employer,' as though there was some sort of equality between a kid who left school and an employer of an enterprise in terms of a bargaining arrangement, is obviously a nonsense and results in these sorts of outcomes where those who are without bargaining power in the labour market find themselves having their conditions of employment stripped away. So that much is clear.

However, what happened in relation to productivity and real wages? In respect of productivity, we see that in New Zealand from 1990 to 1995 GDP per hour worked—which is about as comprehensive a basis as you can get for productivity improvement across the economy—increased by 2.7 per cent over five years. At the same time, in Australia it has increased by 8.6 per cent. It increased by 8.6 per cent against their 2.7 per cent. So much for this myth that this deregulation of the labour market leads to a whole new world of mushrooming productivity. It obviously did not happen there in the way that it happened in this country without that kind of severe deregulation and stripping away of conditions of employment.

What happened in the manufacturing industry was even more astonishing. In manufacturing, output per person employed in New Zealand over the last five years has gone up by 3 1/2 per cent and in Australia by 23 per cent. It has gone up by 23 per cent in Australia as against 3 1/2 per cent in New Zealand. We are looking at very different productivity outcomes across the economy, particularly in manufacturing.

What has happened to real wages? Over the last four years, real average weekly earnings in Australia increased by 5.1 per cent compared with an increase of just 0.7 per cent in New Zealand. In other words, in New Zealand this deregulation of the labour market has meant the stripping away of conditions of employment in a way which has never been seen in that country before and virtual stagnation of real wages. There is no great startling growth, no surge of real wage increases or no whole new light blooming in the workplaces of New Zealand in terms of higher incomes for workers. It just has not happened. Yet in Australia the growth of real wages has been much more significant under our system than it has been in New Zealand since the employment contracts legislation came into place.

When the election was being held prior to these employment contracts being brought in and the then opposition was running with this policy, what did they say the benefits of this policy would be? Increased real wages for New Zealand workers. When the Labour government said that there would be a stripping away of conditions of employment, they said, `Oh, that's just a Labour lie.' What happened after the election? Exactly what the Labour government said would happen: there was a stripping away of conditions of employment. What happened to productivity and real wages? Very little in terms of productivity and virtually nothing in terms of real wages. That is the New Zealand experience. That is what would happen in this country if John Howard had his way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Is the minister aware of a report which indicates that Australians will have to accept inferior product safety standards set by countries under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation agreement? PARA.TAB: Mr Toohey has relied on a report by the APEC Eminent Persons Group but he has been very selective in his use of that document. The report suggests the idea of `tested once, accepted everywhere' but what Brian Toohey does not explain is that the report says that this is a guiding principle which can be put into practice only if all APEC members agree. That is, all governments would have to agree on that, and this government will never agree to anything which affects our high quality standards for products, particularly safety standards.

Nowhere does the report recommend that APEC members should be forced to accept unsafe products, nor does it say that members should not be able to set or enforce safety standards that suit their own citizens. That is exactly opposite to the implication in the article.

I also have to seriously question where Mr Toohey has been in the past year and the quality of his research because for the past 12 months I have certainly been talking publicly on numerous occasions, and in this House, on what my office and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs are doing to ensure product safety standards are not only upheld but improved as we go into the APEC area. We are developing what I call a `culture of safety' and this involves looking at the way we currently set safety standards for products to see if there is not a better way of doing it so that product safety standards do not themselves become barriers to trade.

They have already gone down this path in Europe and they have found that if you develop safety standards based on the types of injuries caused rather than on an individual product basis, as we currently do in Australia, you can allow for more innovation while eliminating more dangerous products. So that is going to be of great benefit to the APEC process. I just do not know how a journalist could get it so wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Can the minister inform the House what progress is being made in combating crime by confiscating the proceeds of crime from criminals?

—I am very happy to be able to advise the House on the way in which the millions of dollars which have gone into the confiscated assets trust fund have been distributed. That fund was established in 1991 as a way of injecting money from those who have exploited Australia by criminal behaviour into the fight against crime. The fund is a key part of our goal as a federal government of making the Australian environment as hostile as possible for people who would wish to pursue criminal activity here.

PARA.TAB: The starting point is that taking organised crime's profits is the most effective disincentive to the committing of further crime. The federal government understands that organised crime has just one goal, and that is profit. Profit is the lifeblood of those groups. We have to do more than just put individual members of those groups behind bars; we have to attack the massive profits that those groups make. That is what our legislation does. It allows us to confiscate money and property from criminals and invest it back in a way that benefits the whole of the community.

Since December 1991, all funds recovered under proceeds of crimes legislation and provisions of the Customs Act have been paid into the confiscated assets trust fund. In all, more than $27 million has been available for allocation. The money is divided equally between law enforcement initiatives and, under the management of my colleague the Minister for Human Services and Health, strategies to reduce drug demand. The most appropriate way to use this money is, firstly, in strengthening our law enforcement purposes and our law enforcement agencies and, secondly, in improving this country's drug rehabilitation and drug education.

Members should know that this not only helps federal authorities but also, where there is successful cooperation between federal and state agencies, benefits state agencies. The way some of those benefits come about can be quite innovative. For example, earlier this year I was in Western Australia and was able to hand over a Beechcraft aircraft worth $150,000 to the Western Australian government, which is now using it as part of its law enforcement arrangements around Kalgoorlie, and it is proving to be a very useful adjunct to the Western Australian law enforcement agencies.

This year we have been able to distribute about $5 1/2 million from the fund to law enforcement projects. The biggest grant of $1.8 million is going to the National Crime Authority; $1.4 million is going to the Australian Federal Police, part of which will be used to develop a computerised investigation system for document based cases; $130,000 is going to the Australian Securities Commission to enhance its database; $290,000 is going to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to improve its screening procedures; over half a million dollars is going to the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board to improve information sharing between federal law enforcement agencies; and grants of the nature of $411,000 are going to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence to develop software packages for easier access to criminal intelligence and to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission for fraud training.

So there is a whole range of projects. I have not been comprehensive in the total disbursements, but you can get a good sense of where the funding is going. An additional $5 1/2 million is going into drug rehabilitation and drug education programs. That, of course, is under the management of my colleague the Minister for Human Services and Health, and she will be making an announcement in that regard in the near future.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Prime Minister to consider and protect the retirement incomes of Australian workers.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days, over eight million Australian contributors to a national compulsory superannuation scheme have been absolutely amazed to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country in this place and elsewhere call the very people that he has to depend upon for the administration of those funds `donkeys' or `lemmings'. That is the sort of terminology we expect to hear from the Prime Minister, but we do not expect those attacks to be made on the very people whom, since May of this year, he has endeavoured to extol as being the managers of the most wonderful scheme this nation has ever seen to ensure that future generations of Australians will be financially independent in their retirement.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it absolutely clear at this stage that the coalition shares the government's objective of improving national savings and investment and retirement incomes. However, we do fear that the proposed system, as introduced by this government, does not necessarily meet those objectives, nor the savings needs of Australians, in a fair and efficient way. It is for that reason that the matter of public importance before the House today—`the failure of the Prime Minister to consider and protect the retirement incomes of Australian workers'—is so absolutely necessary.

On 8 August last, at the launch of the national superannuation education campaign—an initiative of this government, paid for by the Australian taxpayer at a cost of $12.5 million—the Prime Minister described the purposes of the campaign as being `to tell people about superannuation, to involve them with it, to give them some confidence that the system is going to be managed well for them and is going to do good things'. Later on we have seen a scare campaign. That is what we have seen in the last few days, apparently to ensure that we see the `good things'—a little bit of the old tickle, get the old cat-o'-nine-tails out. Apparently, according to the Prime Minister, a bit of abuse here and there helps to tone people's imagination and their mental approach.

The worrying thing is simply this: the Prime Minister is attacking the heart of the trusteeship system, which is the very basis of the superannuation arrangements of this nation. His attacks have ignored the reality that superannuation fund trustees have a fiduciary relationship to nobody except the contributors to those funds. They are accountable for forming an investment strategy that has regard to all aspects of the particular fund. The trustees also have the responsibility of representing members' interests. Consequently, if they fail, fund managers, appointed by trustees, are sacked.

Side by side with the fiduciary responsibilities are the obvious prudential supervision requirements. But above all trustees are required to invest solely for the purpose of providing a retirement benefit for fund members. The important thing is that the direction of the government's policy is quite clearly consistent with the position adopted by the ACTU some years ago in a document called Australia Reconstructed. The basis of that policy put forward then and now carried through in this dubious way was to effectively take the savings of Australian workers and to direct them into social, economic or other priorities which the government of the day saw as being in its interests.

I would like to hear a single member of this government, and certainly the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Elliott), who is at the table today, explain how it is possible to maintain trusteeship responsibilities on the one hand and at the same time to subvert those responsibilities to achieve the objectives of the government. The sole purpose obligation of trustees requires that superannuation investments be made only for the purpose of providing retirement benefits for fund members. Any deflection of superannuation investment from that primary purpose to achieve a socially worthwhile goal or any other goal established by government has the potential to negate the ability of superannuation to realise the retirement income policy objectives for which it has been founded.

Is it any wonder that the confidence of the Australian people in the superannuation policies of this government is falling? In November 1994 the Australian Consumers Council found that 50 per cent of those surveyed believed that superannuation was a poor investment. Several months later Assirt Investment Research warned that confidence in superannuation was falling to crisis levels. In March 1995 the survey showed a further seven per cent fall in the number of people who regarded it as a good investment. Why is this? This survey set down in considerable detail what the responses of people were.

The survey identified a number of reasons for this lack of confidence. Since the Labor Party won power in 1983, there have been over 2,000 major changes to superannuation rules and regulations. The ensuing lack of stability has left many consumers fearful of the security of their investment. The changes have also made our superannuation system one of the most complex in the Western world. A large number of contributors were frustrated by the lack of control and access to their funds. They felt that their financial outcome was entirely in the hands of government or of the funds and that they had no control, while many others were concerned about the erosion of their accounts by fees and government charges—and well they might.

On 10 May 1995, the day after the budget was brought down, our glorious intrepid Prime Minister went on Triple J. It is very important to note the audience that he was talking to. Youth unemployment in this country is now 27 per cent. The group which is affected most by that is those between 15 and 19—exactly the same people listen to Triple J. This is what the Prime Minister told them:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . your audience—
that is the 15- and 19-year-olds listening to him—
will be the first generation of Australians in our history who will have security right through, that is economic security, right through their working lives and beyond.

Whom is he trying to convince—the young people listening to him, the 27 per cent-plus of young people who are unemployed in this country today, or perhaps their parents who are wondering whether being forced into a system developed by the government is such a good idea after all?

PARA.TAB: But the Prime Minister was not in any way put off by this. On 8 August, in terms of his national superannuation education program and to convince people about what a good thing the government's policy was, he said that `someone on average weekly earnings—someone on about $32,000 to $33,000—will retire with a lump sum of just under half a million dollars'. What the public was sold before the last election was legislated tax cuts to commence on 1 January. They were worth $1.8 billion for the first half year and $4 billion in a full year. What the public received was an unfunded promise that most workers would receive a co-payment of up to $1,000 which would lead to a long and prosperous retirement.

What the Prime Minister is saying to people commencing to work in the next century—and I emphasise `in the next century'—is that they will retire on more money or a similar amount of money as they earned. That is wonderful. But that is under one important condition. Are those people going to be working? The very basis of the Prime Minister's formula was that they were going to be working for 40 years without a break—with a four per cent investment return.

How can you explain to the people of Australia? How can you explain to the 25 per cent of people who have recently been in that lucky number to have found jobs that they are in part-time jobs? What I am simply pointing out to the House is this: we are not talking about 100 per cent of the work force who can be guaranteed full-time employment for 30 or 40 years, when the evidence before the Australian people today is as clear as a pikestaff that there will be a growing percentage of them in part-time employment.

But the emphasis of the superannuation program is simply this: that the end benefits were based on the presumption of full-time employment and the presumption of a gradually but steadily rising wage. Today you have 800,000-odd Australians who are unemployed. To tell those people that the superannuation program of this government will give them milk and honey in retirement is gross. It is a gross insult to the integrity of those people, who ask for nothing except the right to work—the one right that has been denied them by this government.

Superannuation does not carry the same Commonwealth commitment as do bank deposits. But this Prime Minister assures everybody that the system works so well that what goes in will be multiplied over and over and come out as that fantastic figure of half a million dollars per working person. How can he relate that to the women of Australia—the hundreds and thousands of women who are now in the work force whose average salary levels are well below those of males in the same industry, whose expectation of work is substantially less because of family requirements?

Your policy does nothing at all for those people. Your so-called small payments system is a sham. It is based on the presumption that, if you had three or four jobs—and that is often the situation faced by those women—you now can consolidate your old funds into one fund; well and good.

Let us look at the next situation: many of those women are working for more than one employer, but they are not allowed to consolidate their funds because your trade union mates will not let them do so. And what is the outcome of that? It is quite simple: unnecessary fees and taxes. And what is the outcome of all of that? At the end of the day those people have very little—certainly not half a million dollars! Let me give an example from a letter which was written to me by one woman. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I have recently received my benefit statement as at 31 December 1994 and was appalled to see that my total retirement credit had shrunk from $640.46—
a very wealthy person; she will certainly be getting half a million dollars—
contributed by my employer to $426.62 as shown in the following calculations.
The contribution tax that that person paid on that very small amount of money was $88.28. She began with $640; she ended with $426.

PARA.TAB: I have a worse case here—worse, despite the $12.5 million spent in an advertising program. This woman was 65 years of age. She did not have to be forced into superannuation, but she was. What does she have to show for it? This woman's account had eroded to $250. But she was over 65, and no-one told her that she could access her money. So between the ages of 55 and 65 she continued to pay the charges and taxes that were levied unnecessarily—year in and year out. At the end of the day, she finally wrote to her member of parliament and said, `What sort of a system is this? I'm going backwards and I'm 65 years of age!'

Is it any wonder that so many Australians no longer have confidence in this government and no longer have confidence in the system which is quite obviously incapable of looking after their interests either now or in the future? The whole promise of the superannuation proposal as put forward by the government is a sham. We support superannuation; we support savings. You have to when you consider that in 1983 this government inherited a national foreign debt of $23 billion, yet here we are in 1995 owing $180 billion—an increase of 800 per cent on what Australians now owe the world. Yes, we have to save, but you as a government have got no right to be giving the Australian people such a dubious bill of sale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott The Hon R.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ELLIOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in this debate on the matter of public importance and to deal with some of the issues raised by the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). We heard the member for Bradfield say, `Yes, the opposition supports national savings and, yes, we support the retirement incomes policy.' One would have thought that that might have led the member for Bradfield to actually detail the opposition's approach to these issues. I was waiting during the 15 minutes of the member for Bradfield's contribution for him to outline what the opposition stands for. At this stage all we have got from the member for Bradfield and the opposition is their existing policy.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said earlier this year that their policy of 1993 in this area was still a pretty good policy. What did the 1993 opposition policy on superannuation say? Fightback said that they were going to freeze the superannuation guarantee at three per cent or whatever level it was when they came to office. So their policy still stands, despite a few of the winks and the nods that the member for Bradfield is giving around various sections of the financial and superannuation industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much detail in your speeches either—no more detail than there was today. Clearly the opposition's approach at this stage is no more than the freeze on the superannuation guarantee or no more than their approach when they were last in office where superannuation was very much the prerogative of the privileged few. It was either the public sector or a small segment of the non-public sector work force that had superannuation arrangements. Indeed, superannuation coverage at that time stood at about 40 per cent of the work force, with very substantial tax concessions to those on high incomes. For the vast majority of the work force, there was no superannuation access at all. Today, 93 per cent of the population has superannuation. The number of women—the member for Bradfield referred to this—with superannuation has grown from about 25 per cent in 1983 to 85 per cent today.

PARA.TAB: Superannuation has become increasingly important. The fact that we have the debates that we do on superannuation is by virtue of the fact that the government has a comprehensive strategy—a strategy where superannuation is designed to have a dual impact: firstly, to boost national savings and, secondly, to ensure that we do have comprehensive retirement income strategies built around the significant contribution that the superannuation guarantee arrangements have provided; that is, phasing through to nine per cent by the year 2002. The important budget initiatives this year provide for a three per cent employee contribution, phasing in at one per cent per year from 1997, and a matching contribution from the government, phasing in at that time, to achieve a total contribution of 15 per cent by the year 2002. The impact of that will be immense in terms of both savings and retirement income strategies.

It will ensure that retirement incomes are maximised. Those who have a long period in the work force obviously will get a substantial benefit from superannuation. People who have 30 to 40 years in the work force at the 15 per cent rate will clearly have a big retirement income through superannuation. But we should not assume, as the opposition often tries to, that only those who will be in the work force for 40 years will get a benefit. The studies and the models that are being done show that people will be able to get a combination in their age pension—part-age pension and part-superannuation—and that they will get a higher retirement income through these arrangements than they would have got had they not had any superannuation.

In 1983, the opposition was quite happy to have 60 per cent of the work force with no superannuation coverage at all. Many people in my electorate and the electorate of the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is in the House, did not get superannuation at all under the regime that was the previous government's approach. We now come to what the government is doing and this matter of public importance, which states:
The failure of the Prime Minister to consider and protect the retirement incomes of Australian workers.

SPEECH.PARA: What a load of nonsense. The fact of the matter is that the government has continually taken steps to protect and ensure that the prudential arrangements for superannuation are enhanced. There has been a series of measures. The member for Bradfield referred to the fact that there have been a number of changes as far as superannuation is concerned. What have those changes been designed to do? They have been designed to provide more security, provide a strengthening of the role of the regulator, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, ensure accountability to fund members and ensure that we do have a regime which is delivering outcomes to fund members and puts clear responsibility on the trustees.

PARA.TAB: Nothing that has been said by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or anyone else has suggested that we are seeking to walk away in any sense from that clear trustee responsibility. Indeed, when we are having a debate about this issue it is probably worth while that I refer briefly to a few of the things that the current act provides for. In the area of the covenants to be included in the governing rules of the funds, the act says, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to formulate and give effect to an investment strategy that has regard to the whole of the circumstances of the entity including, but not limited to, the following:
(i)the risk involved in making, holding and realising, and the likely return from, the entity's investments having regard to its objectives and its expected cash flow requirements;
(ii)the composition of the entity's investments as a whole including the extent to which the investments are diverse or involve the equity in being exposed to risk from inadequate diversification;
(iii)the liquidity of the entity's investments having regard to its expected cash flow requirements;
(iv)the availability of the entity to discharge its existing and prospective liabilities;

Nothing that has been suggested by the government moves away from that. The SIS regime makes it clear that it is the responsibilities of the trustees to develop a diversified investment strategy and to account for that to

fund members. We are saying quite clearly, as we have done repeatedly, that it is the trustees' responsibility to do that. We are also saying they need to ensure that fund investment is diversified and the risk spectrum is spread. Investment should not be made through an unimaginative approach which has all the investment located in a handful of blue-chip stocks. It needs to be spread across the range of opportunities that a prudent financial fund manager should be seeking.

PARA.TAB: That is gradually occurring. The key thing that we have been saying is that we are keen to ensure that process is done well, that those fund managers who have been setting the best practice standard are not an isolated few—in fact, that they become the norm for fund managers—and that we keep enhancing that best practice strategy. That is what this whole debate is about. It is not about in any sense removing the trustees' obligations and the duties they clearly have under the act. No-one has suggested anything of the sort. Rather, it is about trying to ensure we get the very best outcomes, because trustees do, in many instances, seek the direct involvement of the fund managers in ensuring their fulfilment of investment strategy.

The law makes it clear that the trustees are entitled to engage people to assist in delivering the outcomes that their responsibilities require. But we want to ensure that we do not have the situation that occurred in 1994, when funds did not perform as well as they should have because a lot of fund managers sold bonds to the detriment of fund members. Things can be done better than in 1994.

One of the things we have been seeking to do is ensure that the education program that the member for Bradfield referred to is focused on trustees getting across their obligations. We are seeking to ensure the range of new trustees who have come in since the law was enacted are fully aware of all their obligations and all the opportunities that exist for them to help to contribute to this dynamic industry in the best possible way. This will help ensure we get the best fund performance at the end of the day for superannuation fund assets.

The government has taken a whole range of measures in this area. The substantial enhancement of the powers of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission adds to that protection and that security without, in any sense, obviating the trustees' legal fiduciary duties. For instance, the annual report of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission tabled in the parliament showed that nearly 800 fund audits had been conducted in the last year by the ISC. These fund audits included funds of all different sizes and arrangements. The ISC concluded from that that most funds are run satisfactorily. There certainly were some shortcomings, but they were of a minor nature.

Funds, as the ISC has reported, were overwhelmingly receptive to fixing measures where any problems arose. Where there were particular problems that the ISC needed to pursue, funds were not backward in taking such action. For instance, money is being restored to one fund which had been embezzled by its financial controller. The financial controller's actions have been referred to the New South Wales police. A small investment manager in Queensland has been referred to the Queensland police. A Queensland auditor has been banned from auditing superannuation funds as a result of the ISC's actions. There has also been a commitment on the part of the government—indeed, the legislation will be debated later this week in the parliament—to ensure a strengthening of the external audit provisions as far as the act is concerned.

The whole reporting requirements in relation to superannuation have been improved dramatically. Members, on joining a fund, get details about what the fund's arrangements are, what the investment strategy is and what prospective fund members can expect from it. They then get an annual statement with details about the fund and its performance over that year. In addition, on leaving a fund, they get a detailed statement of what the fund asset has achieved during the members' time in the fund.

The government has taken very strong measures to protect small superannuation balances. This was one of the big things the member for Bradfield mentioned in his contribution. The member for Bradfield talked about someone who got a statement in December 1994 relating to the erosion of their superannuation through fees and charges. The government identified that problem early. The fact is that the Treasurer (Mr Willis) made a statement on 28 June 1994 indicating that action was being taken by the government to resolve that. New measures came into effect from 1 July this year to protect small superannuation balances from being eroded by fees and charges.

The experience the member for Bradfield referred to cannot, as he well knows, be repeated because there are now protective measures that prevent that from happening. Those measures mean that the industry has had to provide protection for small superannuation balances. When we make a comparison with other forms of investment, can we see any other form of investment which has that same protection against fees and charges in the way that now applies to superannuation?

In addition, when people still are not satisfied with the complaint handling arrangements from a fund, the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal can now deal with those complaints in a fair, efficient and quick method. The Superannuation Complaints Tribunal will have its powers strengthened by legislation, which is in the House this week, to ensure that it can deal with medical evidence matters and matters to do with personal superannuation products from life offices. So all of those key things that have been introduced to add to the protection of the superannuation regime and the protection of the savings of Australians have contributed to superannuation in this important area.

But then we come to trying to ensure that, as those superannuation assets grow, fund managers have the diversity and the imagination to ensure innovation through fund performance over time. We do encourage the funds not to take too much of a short-term view. We do encourage the community not to be too focused by the short-term fund performance for one year. We do encourage action to see superannuation as the long-term savings vehicle that it is.

Only in the last couple of weeks I have indicated that measures will be taken to ensure superannuation fund performance is measured not just in an annual statement perspective but also in five-yearly measures that provide insights into fund performance over the longer term. It is all part of encouraging this broadening and deepening of the superannuation industry investment strategy. We want to provide access to superannuation and to improve the performance for the fund member to make sure super works most effectively for the nation.

About 85 per cent of superannuation assets today are being reinvested in Australia. We need to ensure that, both within that 85 per cent and the many not currently being invested in Australia, we get the breadth of investment across both blue-chip and green-chip companies. The net benefit needs to flow through to small and medium sized businesses and to the whole community rather than in a narrow phase of investment, as some criticise the industry for at the moment. All of these things point to the government's achievements in the area of superannuation policy for all Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to this federal government, in every backyard throughout the land—the length and breadth of Australia—a new tree is going to spring up somewhere alongside the disused incinerator and the old lemon bush. The tree is a money tree, growing higher and more dense every day with fresh green banknotes. The government even puts out a depiction of this in its booklet about superannuation—the money tree that is going to grow up in your backyard.

PARA.TAB: This of course is your compulsory superannuation account into which a projected 15 per cent of your income will go by the year 2002. The problem is, at least in this country, that banknotes are not green, unless you are talking about monopoly money, and there are many reasons for believing that this superannuation scheme will have much more in common with the disused incinerator or the lemon tree.

The federal government's compulsory superannuation scheme has been widely spruikered throughout the country in a $12.5 million advertising campaign. It is all part of the phoney election war that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is fighting at present. But it is actually heavy on fairy tale and very light on realism. The fairy tale goes a bit like this: if you pay your hard won readies into a superannuation fund, at the end of 40 years of diligent contributions you will find a pot of gold at the end of the superannuation rainbow.

Against the backdrop a few weeks ago of the Berlei lingerie factory, the erstwhile David Jones suit salesman, now Prime Minister Paul Keating, told the assembled throng of ordinary workers on average weekly earnings that they would find half a million dollars in their pots of superannuation gold at the end of their working lives. The setting chosen for this announcement was cynical in the extreme, because women top the list of great losers in a scheme that prioritises superannuation at the expense of all other savings vehicles. The fairy tale presented in the budget is that everyone is employed, everyone is a member of a couple, everyone works for an unbroken 40 years and that the real rate of return on superannuation funds will be four per cent. But of course the reality is very different.

Let me deal with some of the assumptions which underlie the government's superannuation policy. Firstly, the scheme assumes that a person starts to work at the age of 25 and continues to the age of 65 without a break. But we all know that up to one-third of workers are being thrown out of work at the age of 50 in Australia. We know that women spend on average 18 years in the work force, compared with an average of 39 years for men. In fact current research suggests that, even with predicted future increases in female labour force participation, women will spend no more than 28 years on average in paid employment—a long way short of the 40 years on which this scheme is based.

Women's earnings are still much lower than men's. They are also disproportionately concentrated among low-paid workers. In Australia, nearly 50 per cent of female employees are in just three occupations: typists and stenographers, sales assistants and data processing. As a result of broken employment and low levels of lifetime income, women accumulate insubstantial superannuation earnings. On average, male superannuation fund members of retirement age have superannuation assets double those of women.

The retirement income modelling task force estimated that, even with the improvements in superannuation cover under the superannuation guarantee charge, women will accrue only around half the benefits of men because of differences in average earning levels and paid work force participation patterns. Yet, interestingly, the budget makes the assumption that `most people will go through their working life and retire as a member of a couple'.

The second assumption is that you are guaranteed an adequate retirement income from your superannuation. But, as anybody who has looked at superannuation even in the slightest degree can attest, there is no guarantee of any particular return on your money. The result depends on a range of factors. If the fund fails, as did Beneflex in Queensland, people will find that the money tree has shed all its leaves and died during a spell of economic permafrost. So much for that assumption.

The third assumption is that everybody goes into retirement with a partner. In fact, as I said before, this is cited in the budget documentation itself. Yet we know in Australia that four in 10 marriages end in separation and divorce over a lifetime, with women tending to take a share of their former partner's superannuation at the time of the separation and divorce to provide immediate income or to pay off their share of the house—leaving nothing for them in old age. In fact, five per cent of women 45 years old and over in Australia have never married. In the 1991 census, the last census figures available, over one million Australians were living alone. So this assumption that the scheme is based upon—that everybody goes into retirement with a partner—is simply factually wrong and therefore undermines the scheme for many people.

Fourthly, the government is assuming that inflation will be three per cent a year, wages will grow by four per cent and investment earnings after fees and charges will be seven per cent a year. Yet, if you look at the details from the funds themselves, according to the Association of Superannuation Funds the 30-year real rate of return as to 30 June last year was just 2.6 per cent a year. Clearly the volatility of markets affects the returns year by year. A 30-year return rate of just 2.8 per cent is far below what has been assumed as the basis of this fund: the assumptions upon which the Prime Minister says to the people of Australia, `You're going to get in 2041'—mind you—`if you've worked for 40 years, something like half a million.' The assumption is simply wrong.

Finally, the government promotes this scheme as being fair to all Australians. But the tax levied on contributions and fund earnings is a flat tax. Women, who earn less and on average work many fewer years, will receive nowhere near the amounts that have been suggested by the Prime Minister. The scheme favours dual income families over single income families. The bulk of tax concessions on employers' contributions flow through to men, and disproportionately to high income earners. Young savers and low income earners will have the problem of generating enough savings to pay off the house mortgage well before retirement age and having backup savings in the event of an emergency such as a redundancy.
ACOSS, in a report which was released in October 1995, heavily criticises the government and says, `Basically what we are talking about is a highly flawed scheme.' In fact their summary is this:

SPEECH.PARA: Overall, the superannuation scheme as it currently stands is deeply flawed and highly risky.

ACOSS—representing the welfare sector, representing the poor, representing the people whom this government and this Prime Minister pretend to represent—says that this is a totally flawed scheme. Yet you have the government running around spending $12.5 million to convince people that they should be in a compulsory scheme. Think of the absurdity of that. ACOSS and a whole group of agencies recently said:

PARA.TAB: Many low income people will be forced to give up an unjustifiably large amount of their wages during times, such as child rearing, when their basic expenses are highest. Yet the scheme will provide these people with little or no extra assistance in retirement, while offering very large improvements for many wealthier people.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the judgment of ACOSS. This is a scheme which is flawed. As the previous speaker for the coalition said, there is no question on the part of the coalition that we need a retirement incomes saving policy, but we need a policy that is not merely political rhetoric and not merely a slogan which is exercised by the Prime Minister. We need a policy which will work and which will deliver true benefits to the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Far from being a tree upon which money will grow—you will believe that if you believe that there are fairies at the bottom of the garden—in this country, this is something akin to a lemon tree and that is the way people will see it as years go by. Far from providing certainty and security for the people of Australia which they can look forward to in their retirement, this is a scheme which will just contribute to the anxiety of Australians who already feel a great degree of insecurity about the way in which this country is being led. Nothing in this legislation, nothing in this proposal and nothing in this scheme will remove the anxiety of any Australians looking forward to their retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first heard the terms of this matter of public importance which has been brought forward by the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) I thought that there must have been a mistake in the wording of it or in the subject that was being chosen. I simply could not believe that members of the opposition would deliberately choose to direct the attention of the community, let alone the attention of this parliament, to the question of superannuation retirement income. When I checked with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, the member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), he said, `No, Bob; they are the terms in which that MPI is being brought forward.' He asked whether I would be interested in supporting him. I said, `Paul, I would always be interested in supporting you.' I can now confirm that commitment and that belief on my part because there is nothing that the member for Parramatta said in his brilliant response to the member for Bradfield with which I would disagree. Despite the member for Bradfield's expertise in this area, he would agree that his presentation today was a little less than adequate. The parliamentary secretary responded to that.

PARA.TAB: Let me respond to some of the points that were made by the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), who supported the shadow spokesman, the member for Bradfield. I can understand the difficulty that the member for Menzies faced. I can also appreciate the personal courage that he displayed in getting up to support the member for Bradfield in presenting a position and making out a case which is completely untenable.

TALK.START.PARA: —He really wanted to talk about the GST.

—No, he did not; the member for Menzies has said quite enough about the GST. Now that you have reminded me, I was going to ask whether it was possible that superannuation contributions could have a 15 per cent levy imposed on them, but I thought that would be most ungenerous. PARA.TAB: One of the points that I wanted to refer to which was made by the member for Menzies was that he claimed—I am not misquoting him—that ACOSS referred to the totality of the Australian superannuation system as a totally flawed scheme. The member for Menzies knows that ACOSS did no such thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's in their bulletin.

—They did not refer to this as a totally flawed scheme. In some of those nitpicking points that you chose to refer to there may have been some substance. But you should not just look at nitpicking points; you should look for the substance itself. You have to look for the substance. That was why I simply could not believe that the opposition would come forward and draw the attention of the parliament and the national community to an area where they had been so deficient. PARA.TAB: I was in this parliament in 1983 and before, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have mentioned those wage plugs up in my electorate. You people who were in government did not give people the opportunity to have any access to superannuation benefits, to supplement their age pensions when they retired and to give them that bit of extra retirement income, security and comfort. No fear, you did not. Why then would you draw the attention of the national community to the fact that in 1983 only 40 per cent of Australian wage and salary earners had any access to superannuation? Why would you want to remind them? Why in the process would you want to remind them that the percentage of women wage and salary earners in Australia in 1983 who had access to superannuation was 25 per cent? Why would you want to remind them? I will tell you what we want to remind them about. That 40 per cent that we inherited from you is now 90 per cent. That 25 per cent of women that we inherited from you is now 85 per cent. You know that your superannuation arrangements were not only income discriminatory because they were available to the richest, the wealthiest and the highest income earners in the community, but they were also gender discriminatory because they were not available to women. There were 25 per cent of them under you and 85 per cent under us.

I will tell honourable members two of the reasons why 87 per cent of the Australian community endorsed the superannuation arrangements that exist in Australia. First, because they have been reformed and they have been reformed well. Secondly, our approach has been articulated and it has been articulated well by that fellow sitting at the dispatch box—the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer. He has had the particular responsibility for the carriage of these arrangements. He has been able to take them through all the caucus committees and through the cabinet and into this parliament. He has taken it out there to the national community as well and 87 per cent of those people out there—100 per cent in my electorate of Charlton—endorse it and applaud his efforts because both he and this government gave them an opportunity to have access to superannuation benefits which will provide all of that additional security that they should have in their retirement.

I want to emphasise some of the essential elements which underpin our whole approach to the question of retirement income. The claim that was made in this matter of public importance refers to the government's failure to consider and protect the retirement incomes of Australian workers. That is why I could not believe it. The parliamentary secretary will confirm that I said to him, `They can't be serious. Is that really what they're bringing forward as an MPI today?', despite my regard for the member for Bradfield. We all know what has happened in the electorate of Bradfield. Why your colleagues, as I have said to him before, would choose to see you leave this place is beyond me. There will not be anyone on the opposition side who knows anything about superannuation. These are the points which underpin our whole approach to superannuation or to retirement security: first of all, the safety net of the age pension. We made sure that reached 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, and we are keeping it there. No-one in Australia falls through that safety net. In addition to that, we made sure that we will supplement it as a result of superannuation.
