PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a contribution to the debate on this important bill—the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Transfer of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1995. The bill will restructure the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation in the following form: the HLIC will be reconstituted as a new government owned company established under the Corporations Law and subject to regulation by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. As is presently the case, the new company's non-borrowing liabilities will be government guaranteed; the new company will be fully capitalised in line with the requirements of the ISC; the HLIC's existing portfolio of insurance policies—the `old book'—will at the time of its restructure become the responsibility of the Commonwealth in exchange for which the Commonwealth will receive the HLIC's capital and reserves; and the new HLIC company will be contracted by the Commonwealth to manage the run-off of the old book. Claims arising from the old book will be met from the future budget outlays.

PARA.TAB: The bill will also repeal the Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965, which originally established the HLIC, as well as the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Act 1990, which provided the authority for the Commonwealth to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to a private organisation.

It is a fairly innocuous bill until you get down to the financial impact. The estimated financial implications of the proposal are as follows: an estimated negative outlay to the budget of approximately $100 million in 1995-96, reflecting the return to the Commonwealth of the HLIC's capital and financial reserves after allowance for the capitalisation costs of the new HLIC.

Talk about deja vu—it has all the hallmarks of the Cain-Kirner years in the Victorian parliament and the Labor government which took control of the Victorian parliament in 1982. How well I recall that time when the labor government, the Cain government, was elected to power in Victoria. All the smart financial experts of the Australian Labor Party came into government and they were going to play Larry Dooley. They were going to empty all of the hollow logs in the Victorian statutory authorities. The hollow logs that they referred to were all of the reserve funds in a range of things like water boards and hospitals. They were going to teach us how modern money management worked.

How well I remember the Hon. David White, who was then the finance spokesman in the upper house in Victoria, the Hon. Bill Landeryou, the industry spokesman at that time, and the Hon. Rob Jolly, who was the Treasurer of Victoria, and all their claims about how they would manage the finances of Victoria. They managed them all right. Forty-two thousand million dollars of debt and accumulated liabilities later, the Labor government in Victoria were drummed out of office.

The genesis of the hollow logs theory came about as a result of the setting up of a public bodies review committee under the chairmanship of Dr Kevin Foley. That committee was pretty well represented by people such as David White from the ALP, Steve Crabb from the ALP, and Rob Jolly—all of those people who thought they knew something about modern money management, as they termed it. The implication was they would get all this money out of the hollow logs—out of the water boards, where they had reserves for the future requirements of their operations, and out of hospital reserve funds—and put it to good use. That may have sounded all right in theory, but in practice their financial skills were incompetent. Here we see the federal government going down a similar path—$100 million out of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation in capital and financial reserves. That is what the government has its eye on—the financial reserves of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

We know that the ALP government are desperate for money in the federal sphere, as they were in 1982 when they came into government in Victoria. They were going to do big things in Victoria. They believed that they could put these reserve funds to good use, as they called it. Instead of having some reserves to fall back on in difficult financial times, or in times of expansion by water boards when providing additional infrastructure and facilities for the delivery of water to a whole range of areas throughout Victoria—and any building programs that hospitals might have retained reserve funds for—using the modern money management techniques of the state ALP under the Cain-Kirner government, what they did was pirate all that money and waste it. They put it into all the shonky schemes that they could dream up. In fact, they frittered away the magnificent reserves that had been accumulated over the Bolte, Hamer and Thompson years.

When they ultimately went out of government in 1992, just 10 years later, not only had those reserve funds been plundered from those authorities but also the government had got themselves into a situation of having $42,000 million of debt and unfunded liabilities. Victoria is still reeling from the impact of the losses and debt that were accumulated by these so-called financial whiz-kids. They were hopelessly out of their depth. The thing that concerns me about the tactic being used by the government for the acquisition of capital and financial reserves from the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is that the same thing could occur.

I do not know whether the minister handling this bill will come into the House and explain what that $100 million will be used for. The capitalisation costs of setting up the new Housing Loans Insurance Corporation should not be too great. The question is: what happens to the balance of that money? If the government employ anything like the modern money management techniques of the former Labor government in Victoria, that does not augur well for the taxpayers, or for the people who have been using the services of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to insure their loans.

I wish to bring that matter to the attention of the House because I have had first-hand knowledge of what happened in the Victorian parliament and of the frightful waste of money that went on during the period of the Tricontinental debacle, the shonky loans involved with the Victorian Economic Development Corporation, and the Pyramid housing funds debacle. There was a succession of failures and mismanagement of money. They all accumulated and, ultimately, the Labor Party in Victoria were drummed out of office for their deplorable financial management and the debt and liability they created for Victoria.

Admittedly, the statutory authorities involved in Victoria were different from the one we are discussing. They consisted of water boards, hospitals and organisations like that. But their reserve funds were put there for a very good purpose: to ensure the financial viability of those organisations to meet with any crisis that might occur or for use for any planning or construction works that might be required. To rob those statutory reserves—which is what the Labor government did at the time—and put the money into some of the schemes that the government did was culpable negligence in the management of the finances of Victoria.

The process put in place in the John Cain years was continued when Premier Joan Kirner took over. At one stage, their financial management got so out of hand that the money to pay their public sector employees was on a merry-go-round. Departments were paying staff from other departments. It was not unusual for the police force to be paid with a cheque from the education department, and vice versa. They even got to the stage of not paying their bills.

The conservation, forests and lands department, at the time Joan Kirner was minister, left 180,000 accounts unpaid for over 12 months. The accounts accumulated and, eventually, the situation was brought to the attention of the state parliament. The traders, who had been holding these debts for the Victorian Labor government, finally blew the whistle on them. That added to the government's problems and, ultimately, led to their dismissal from office.

I trust that the minister is listening to my comments about the use of financial reserves and capital from statutory authorities. I trust that the government has a mechanism in place whereby that $100 million can be put to better use than the use it was put to by the Victorian state government during the Cain-Kirner years from 1982 to 1992.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1995Cognate bills:INCOME TAX (FRANKING DEFICIT) AMENDMENT BILL 1995INCOME TAX (DEFICIT DEFERRAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 28 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.
The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995 will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes 10 measures which give effect to announcements in the 1995-96 budget.
The bill is mostly drafted in the new style emerging from the tax law improvement project. This will help taxpayers and their advisers in understanding the proposed changes.
The 1995-96 budget included a number of measures relating to capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments relating to value shifting

PARA.TAB: The bill proposes amendments to division 19A of part IIIA, which operates to prevent the creation of capital losses or reduction of capital gains realised on the disposal of shares or loans in a company. Losses can be created, or gains reduced, by shifting value out of the shares or loans through the transfer of assets to commonly owned companies for low or nil consideration. Where a value shift is taken to have occurred, the cost bases of shares and loans in the transferor company are reduced to reflect the transferred value. The proposed amendments will generally operate to reduce the costs for taxpayers in complying with division 19A and to rectify certain anomalies in its current operation.

Compliance costs will be reduced by enabling companies to transfer depreciable assets generally at their written down value, without the need to make cost base adjustments, provided that the market value of the assets is not substantially greater. Companies will also be able to group some assets that are transferred rather than deal with them on an asset by asset basis.

A simplified test will also be applied for assets acquired prior to the time at which the transferor and transferee companies came under common ownership. This measure will simplify the operation of the law, reduce uncertainty and thereby reduce compliance costs.

An anti-avoidance measure is included in the bill so that division 19A will apply to the creation and transfer of rights relating to an asset where the asset has not itself been transferred. Where the consideration for the transfer of the new asset is less than its market value, a value shift will be taken to have occurred.

This bill will also make a number of other technical amendments to division 19A. These amendments, which will have no significant impact on revenue, will apply to transfers of assets after 7.30 p.m. AEST on 9 May 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: Increase in personal use asset thresholds

PARA.TAB: The bill increases the thresholds applicable to both listed and non-listed personal use assets to $500 and $10,000 respectively. The amendment to increase the thresholds for listed and non-listed personal use assets will apply to disposals of assets occurring on or after 1 July 1995. The amendments will result in a cost to revenue of up to $2 million per year.

SPEECH.PARA: Taxable Australian assets

PARA.TAB: The bill will clarify the provisions relating to the disposal of certain taxable Australian assets. Some taxpayers have argued that gains on the disposal of taxable Australian assets used solely to produce franked dividends or income subject to withholding tax in Australia—such as certain shares in Australian companies and assets used in a permanent establishment in Australia—are not subject to capital gains tax.

This interpretation of the law is contrary to the clear intention of parliament. The amendments will ensure that capital gains tax will apply appropriately to disposals by non-residents of all taxable Australian assets and, thereby, will give effect to the intention underlying the existing law. They will apply to disposals of taxable Australian assets on or after 20 September 1985, which is the date from which capital gains tax applies. The financial impact of this measure is unquantifiable.

SPEECH.PARA: Exempt receipts

PARA.TAB: The bill contains measures that will extend the existing capital gains tax relief which applies to a gain realised on the disposal of shares in a foreign company where the disposal also gives rise to a tax exempt non-portfolio dividend. The capital gain is reduced by the amount of the exempt dividend as though the dividend was taxable. Currently, capital gains tax relief applies in relation to the disposal of shares in foreign companies which were created after 25 June 1992.

The bill proposes that capital gains tax relief will also be available in relation to disposals of shares in foreign companies where the shares were created before 26 June 1992. This measure will apply to disposals occurring from the 1990-91 year of income, which is the year from which the exemption provided for non-portfolio dividends also applies.

A related measure will ensure that disposals of shares which take place after 7.30 p.m. AEST on 9 May 1995 and which give rise to non-portfolio dividends from foreign companies which are exempt from income tax, will only qualify for capital gains tax relief to the extent that the dividends are not paid out of a share capital account, share premium account or revaluation reserve of the foreign company.

The bill also modifies the existing general capital gains tax relief which applies in relation to gains realised on the disposal of assets where a capital amount is expressly included, in whole or in part, in the assessable income of a taxpayer. The existing general capital gains tax relief will be modified to apply specifically to disposals of rights to receive eligible termination payments. The amendments will apply to disposals taking place after 7.30 p.m. AEST on 9 May 1995. The financial impact of these measures is unquantifiable.

SPEECH.PARA: Compulsory rollover of assets

PARA.TAB: The bill will provide that, where a company disposes of an asset to a related company and the disposal would give rise to a capital loss, a compulsory capital gains tax rollover will generally apply in relation to the transfer of the asset. An exception is provided, subject to safeguards, where the company into which the loss asset is transferred is to be sold or floated within a specified time period. These amendments will apply to transfers of assets between related companies taking place after 7.30 p.m. AEST on 9 May 1995. They will prevent a potentially significant risk to revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment or replacement of trust deeds

PARA.TAB: The bill provides that a capital gains tax rollover will be available in relation to the disposal of the assets of a complying approved deposit fund that would otherwise occur as a consequence of the conversion of the ADF to a complying superannuation fund. A rollover will also be available in relation to a disposal of the assets of an existing complying ADF or complying superannuation fund where the trust deed of the ADF or superannuation fund is amended or replaced in order to comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993.

The rollover will be available only where there is no change in the assets of the fund or interest of members in the fund as a consequence of the conversion of the ADF to a superannuation fund, or the amendment or replacement of the trust deed of the ADF or superannuation fund. This measure will apply to disposals of assets taking place on or after 12 January 1994, the date from which certain amendments to the CGT relating to settlements of trusts and transfers of property to trusts took effect. The revenue impact of this proposal is insignificant.

The bill will amend the dividend imputation provisions as a result of the increase in the company tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent with effect from the 1995-96 income year. The amendments, which will apply from 1 July 1995, will allow companies to record franking credits and debits and distribute imputation credits to shareholders by reference to tax paid at 36 per cent. The value of existing 33 per cent and 39 per cent franking credits will be preserved for shareholders.

The amendments will reduce compliance costs for most companies because they will convert from the present dual franking account system to a single franking account. The bill will also correct certain defects in the current dividend imputation provisions relating to life insurance companies. The amendments will apply from the time the defects in the current provisions first arose. One amendment will prevent an unintended gain to the revenue and the other amendment will prevent a significant potential loss to the revenue.

As part of the dividend imputation amendments, the bill also provides for the calculation of class C franking deficit tax and deficit deferral tax. These taxes are imposed by the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill 1995 and the Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Amendment Bill 1995 respectively. These separate bills are required for constitutional reasons.

In the 1995-96 budget the government announced a measure to deny franking credits for profit shifting adjustments. Under the current imputation system for company taxation, transfer pricing or non-arms-length dealing adjustments resulting in additional tax payable by an Australian resident company will give rise to a franking credit. This provision of a franking credit largely negates the additional tax payable by the resident company because the profits, which have been taxed under the transfer pricing and non-arms-length dealing adjustment provisions, have already been shifted or misallocated offshore and are not actually in Australia.

Accordingly, the franking credits arising from the payment of the additional company tax assessed as a result of the transfer pricing adjustments can be used to frank profit distributions that would not otherwise be franked dividends and subject to the relevant tax relief measures. The proposed amendment will ensure that the Australian revenue is not disadvantaged by international transfer pricing practices or non-arms-length dealings which misallocate or shift profits offshore.

The Treasurer (Mr Willis) announced in the 1995-96 budget that specific taxation measures would be introduced for the demutualisation of mutual life and general insurance companies. These measures are proposed in this bill. The bill provides that a demutualisation may occur under a specified method and then describes the taxation consequences of certain transactions which may occur in the course of the demutualisation. All of the methods of demutualisation require that the interests of members in the mutual company will be extinguished in exchange for ordinary shares in the demutualised company.

The bill provides that capital gains tax will not apply to the surrender by a member of his or her membership interests in a mutual insurance company or a mutual affiliate company. The bill establishes, for capital gains tax purposes, the date and cost of acquisition of shares acquired by former members as part of the demutualisation process. In relation to a life insurance company, the deemed acquisition cost of shares will be determined by reference to the embedded value of the company. For general insurance companies, the deemed acquisition cost of shares will be determined by reference to the net tangible assets of the company.

No capital loss will be available in relation to the disposal of demutualisation shares and interests prior to the listing of ordinary shares in the demutualised entity. After listing, the deemed cost of acquisition of the shares will be the lesser of the amount calculated by reference to the embedded value or net tangible assets of the company and the last published price at which the demutualisation shares were traded on their first day of trading.

The new provisions substantially relate to the application of the capital gains and losses provisions. However, parallel provisions have been included for transactions which would otherwise lead to amounts being included in the assessable income of a taxpayer. The amendments will apply to only demutualisations of mutual companies that were in existence at 7.30 p.m. AEST on 9 May 1995. The nature of the measure is such that the cost to revenue cannot be reliably estimated.

On 29 November 1994, the Treasurer and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) announced that a form of taxation write-off would be extended to expenditure on new horticultural plantations. The details of the form of write-off were announced on 9 May 1995 as part of the 1995-96 budget. The purpose of the amendments is to give capital expenditure on horticultural plantations, such as orchards and perennial crops, comparable tax treatment to capital expenditure in other industries.

The bill allows taxpayers to write off the original capital expenditure incurred in establishing horticultural plants which are used, or are held ready for use, by taxpayers to produce assessable income in businesses of horticulture. The period over which the expenditure is written off will be based on the effective life of the plants and gives the same rate of deduction as prime cost (or `straight line') depreciation of plant and equipment with the same effective life.

Where effective life is less than three years, there is an immediate write-off for establishment expenditure to the first taxpayer to use the plant, or hold it ready for use, to produce assessable income from a business of horticulture. There is expected to be a cost to revenue of $1 million in 1997-98, $2 million in 1998-99 and $4 million in 1999-2000.

The bill will give effect to the measures announced in the 1995-96 budget relating to immature forests and plantations. This measure is designed to overcome an anomaly that exists in some circumstances where an established but immature plantation or forest is purchased by a taxpayer engaged in forestry operations, and subsequently sold with the timber still standing. This taxpayer may be taxed on the gross value of the standing timber rather than the net profit. The measure provides that where a taxpayer, who is engaged in timber operations and has purchased an established but immature plantation or forest, sells that plantation or forest after 9 May 1995 outside the normal course of business the taxpayer is assessed on the net profit from the sale.
The bill also contains certain anti-avoidance provisions relating to non-arms-length transactions.
There is expected to be a cost to revenue of $1 million in 1995-96 and $4 million in subsequent years.

In the 1995-96 budget the government announced a measure to deny a deduction for expenditure on research and development activities incurred to a private tax exempt body where that expenditure is not fully at risk. Where a company incurs expenditure in relation to research and development activities carried out on its behalf, the arrangements are often structured in such a way that the company receives a guaranteed return for its expenditure.

When expenditure is incurred to a tax exempt body, that body faces no tax liability on its income. Therefore the arrangement may support higher guaranteed returns than an arrangement in which expenditure is incurred to a taxpayer. In effect, the Commonwealth is funding the higher guaranteed return. The company owning the research will derive a tax benefit because of the tax exempt status of the researcher.

The proposed amendment will ensure that companies receive the same taxation treatment for research and development expenditure incurred to private tax exempt entities as is presently provided for expenditure incurred to public tax exempt entities. If there is any guaranteed return for the expenditure, the expenditure will not be deductible. Transitional provisions will protect companies relying on a finance scheme approved by the Industry Research and Development Board before the budget and implemented by 3 August 1995.
There is expected to be a gain to revenue of $20 million in 1995-96, $85 million in 1996-97, $120 million in 1997-98 and $145 million in 1998-99.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Wholesale sales tax—exemption for rice milk

PARA.TAB: The bill proposes to amend the sales tax law to exempt rice milk from sales tax as recently announced by the Treasurer. The amendments will ensure that rice milk is treated for sales tax purposes the same as other similar milk and soy milk beverages.
The cost to revenue of exempting rice milk from sales tax is estimated to be less than $300,000 per annum.

This bill gives effect to the government's 1995-96 budget announcement that new rules will be introduced to limit the circumstances in which trusts can deduct current year and prior year losses. The government is making these changes to stop the significant erosion of revenue that has been occurring through trafficking in trust losses.

The tax law already contains tests which limit the deductibility of losses incurred by companies. The proposed rules that are to apply to trusts will differ in some respects from those that apply to companies, reflecting the different characteristics of trusts. The government has been concerned to ensure that the law operates fairly and has therefore decided that the tests to be satisfied before losses are deductible will vary depending on the type of trust. For example, family trusts will generally be able to deduct losses, provided that members of the same family are the only persons who could benefit from the trust. Special rules will also apply to widely held listed unit trusts. These rules will help to minimise compliance costs for this type of trust.

While fixed trusts will be subject to a continuity of ownership test, non-family discretionary trusts will be subject to continuity of ownership, continuity of control and pattern of distribution tests. This reflects the fact that it is not possible to apply the same beneficial ownership test to discretionary trusts.
Trusts, including family trusts, will be subject to an income injection test to ensure generally that trust losses are not used by outsiders to shelter their income from tax.

Exceptions from these measures are provided for complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts. The measures will also not apply to deceased estates for a reasonable period of administration.

The proposed rules designed to prevent trafficking in trust losses necessarily reflect the complex nature of the different types of trusts. The amendments are therefore lengthy but, as already indicated, they are designed to ensure fairness in the system.

The drafting approach for these amendments follows the new tax law improvement style and the structure follows that of the redrafted company loss provisions which are due to be introduced into parliament later this year.
The estimated gain to revenue from the proposed changes is $90 million in 1995-96, $185 million in 1996-97, $155 million in 1997-98 and $65 million in 1998-99.

Also included in this bill is a measure to give effect to the 1995-96 budget announcement to transfer responsibility for the maintenance of the register of approved occupational clothing from the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to AusIndustry in the Department of Industry, Science and Technology.
This amendment has no effect on revenue.
Full details of the measures in the bills are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members.

I also foreshadow that the government will be moving some amendments to the bill in the House relating to the franking account, capital gains tax, trust losses and forestry plantations provisions. Copies of those amendments and a supplementary explanatory memorandum have been circulated to members. I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995, the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill 1995, and the Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Amendment Bill 1995 contain a range of capital gains tax and income tax measures which were announced in the 1995 budget. As the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has pointed out at some length in his second reading speech, they contain a series of complex measures which go to a number of matters in the tax system, some of which I will touch upon in the time available today.

PARA.TAB: It is notable that the government has taken over five months to produce these bills, which together are some 200 pages of amendments to our tax system, adding to the continued increase in the complexity and the size of taxation law in Australia. In seeking to have these bills debated as quickly as the government is doing now, after taking five months to bring them to this place, there will no doubt be some defects in the legislation which may surface. It is notable that the government already intends to move amendments to its own legislation.

The most controversial aspects of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) relate to a series of provisions—firstly, the transitional provisions for the denial of research and development concessions for private tax exempt syndicates; secondly, the denial of franking rebates for transfer pricing adjustments; thirdly, measures to prevent trafficking in trust losses; fourthly, the write-off of capital expenditure on horticultural plantations; fifthly, certain aspects of the dividend imputation rules; and, finally, the retrospective nature of the imposition of capital gains tax on taxable Australian assets of non-residents.

The bills, on our reading and understanding, create a series of anomalies that ought to be addressed. We will seek to remedy these anomalies by amendments which will be moved at the consideration in detail stage. Rather than deal with all the provisions in the bill, I wish to take the time of the House to just deal with some of the more important provisions which we have concerns about.

The first relates to non-residents and taxable Australian assets. The capital gains tax will apply to gains realised by non-residents on the disposal of taxable Australian assets used solely to produce franked dividends or income subject to withholding tax. The bill inserts proposed new section 160Z(10) to exclude income subject to withholding tax from the capital gains tax exemption under sections 160Z(6) and (9)(a).

The measure is said to simplify and clarify the operation of the existing law and to ensure that the capital gains tax provisions apply as originally intended. The bill, therefore, is intended to overcome the view that assets used in a permanent establishment in Australia to produce income that is subject to withholding tax are exempt from the capital gains tax provisions pursuant to sections 160Z(6) and (9)(a).

The government argues that this interpretation is contrary to the clear intention of parliament as reflected in paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) of the definition of disposal of taxable Australian assets in section 160T. The amendment applies to disposals of taxable Australian assets on or after 20 September 1985. But where a private binding ruling has been issued in relation to the transaction entered into prior to 9 May when the measure was announced, the terms of the ruling prevailed. When capital gains tax was introduced in 1985, the policy was to tax realised gains on taxable Australian assets. There is an argument that taxable Australian assets used to produce exempt income should be exempt.

The coalition generally opposes retrospective tax legislation. There are technical arguments for and against the changes which are sought to be made by the government. Some commentators have said that it is unacceptable to claim that section 160T in some way shows a clear intention to override the clear exemption afforded by section 160Z(6) as section 160T defines what is disposal of a taxable Australian asset. Others have argued that if the tax office wants to attack transactions prior to when the measure was announced—that is, 9 May—then the matter should be decided in the courts.

While it is open to the government to change the law, the government ought to be open and honest about why it makes changes. Using the argument that a situation is clearly contrary to the original intention of parliament to justify retrospectivity, as it does in this case, is not satisfactory. Accordingly, the coalition will be seeking to move amendments in the consideration in detail stage which deal with this problem and overcome the anomaly I have referred to.

The second area in which we have some concerns is in relation to the provisions concerning dividend imputation. The bill makes a number of amendments to the dividend imputation provisions of part IIIA as a result of the change in the company tax rate taking effect from the 1995-96 income year. Companies will be required to establish a class C franking account and to record franking credits and debits and distribute imputation credits to shareholders by reference to tax paid at 36 per cent. The value of class A, 39 per cent, and class B, 33 per cent, franking account balances will be preserved by converting them to the equivalent class C franking account balance.

During their 1995-96 franking year, companies will establish a class C franking account and post class C franking credits and debits to the account. The class C franking account represents company tax paid at 36 per cent. Companies other than life insurance companies will convert their existing class A and B franking account balances to class C franking account at some stage during their 1995-96 year. Therefore, most companies will have only a single franking account. Life insurance companies will retain their class A franking account but will convert their class B franking account.

Companies will be required to convert to class C franking account at the earlier of the time when the first class C franking credit of the company arises or the end of the 1995-96 franking year. A company will still be able to pay class A and B franked dividends although it no longer has class A or B franking accounts. No advantage can arise to a company or shareholder as a result of paying class A or B franked dividends. After a company converts to class C, it can still receive class A or B franked dividends. Class C franking deficit tax and deficit deferral tax will be calculated in the same way as class A and B franking deficit tax and deficit deferral tax.

There are also amendments which seek to correct defects in sections 160AQZA and 160AR as they apply to life insurance companies with the result that mutual life insurance companies will be entitled to franking rebates for franked dividends received through trusts or partnerships, and mutual life companies will not be entitled to deductions for the imputation credits attached to franked dividends received through trusts or partnerships if franking rebates are available.

The Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill and the Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Amendment Bill make consequential amendments to the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Act and the Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Act to impose class C franking deficit tax and class C deficit deferral tax.

The class C franking account amendments apply from 1 July 1995. The amendments to correct defects in life insurance company provisions commence from the time the defects first arose. The mutual life insurance company provisions will apply from 22 August 1990 and the non-mutual life insurance company amendments will apply from 7 December 1990.

We have concerns in relation to one particular issue; namely, the denial of deduction for franking rebates received by a life insurance company via a trust. It appears that the amendment applies retrospectively. Indeed, LIFA have argued that any shareholder life companies which correctly claimed a deduction on a correct interpretation of the law as written should not now, five years later, be forced to refund the tax applicable to the deductions.

I would like to take the time of the House to refer more specifically to the objections that have been raised in relation to this provision. As I said, the Life Investment and Superannuation Association of Australia Inc. has made objections about this. The matter has also been raised by legal firms acting on behalf of companies which would be subject, in an adverse way, to this provision. Their memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: As from 7 December 1990 the plain wording of the ITAA entitled an ordinary (ie non-mutual) life insurance company to the section 160AR deduction. And there is no indication in any Bill, Act, Explanatory Memorandum, Second Reading Speech, published ruling, determination or other public statement by the ATO, or other extrinsic material suggesting that the intention of the Parliament, the Government or the ATO was that a life insurance company could not claim that deduction.

A life insurance company is under a statutory fiduciary duty to act in the best interests of its policy holders. And it may have been in breach of that duty if it failed to claim a deduction to which it was entitled under the plain wording of the ITAA.
In reliance on that plain wording:

.At least one life insurance company . . . claimed the deduction and also acted to its detriment by crediting the after tax earnings (including the tax saved) to its 250,000 superannuation policies on a daily basis since 1990.
.Therefore, neither the Company nor its shareholders benefited from the tax saving.

.If the amendments are retrospective, the Company will not be able to recoup any retrospective tax or penalties from its 250,000 policy holders. Therefore, the Company will have to pay the whole of the aggregate amount from its own resources and those of its shareholders.
The memorandum goes on to state:

The ATO has known about the deduction claims since at least the end of 1994. And yet neither the ATO nor the Government gave any indication prior to 28 September 1995 that the deduction was not intended to be available.

In so far as the failure may have given rise to a perceived defect in the legislation, the responsibility for it surely rests with the Australian tax office and the government, not the companies that have been caught by this changed interpretation of the law. Secondly, having regard to the plain wording of the legislation, a taxpayer cannot be presumed to know what parliament, let alone the government or the Australian tax office, intended in the absence of any written indication of that intention prior to the tabling of this bill on 28 September 1995.

PARA.TAB: Of equal importance is the fact that the Australian tax office has known about the claiming of the deduction since at least late 1994, yet there has been no tax office or government announcement since then foreshadowing any legislative amendment at all. Hence, this company—there may well be other companies in this situation—has continued to act to its detriment since then in the genuine belief that in doing so it was doing no more than complying with the fiduciary duty to its shareholders imposed on it by the Commonwealth Life Insurance Act.

Under the complexity of tax law in Australia—you may recall that in speaking to the general provisions here I referred to amendments to make changes in section 160AQZA, let alone going into numerals, Roman numerals and (a)s and (b)s, which you can go down to—you have a company, with all the best legal advice in the world, reliant upon that legal advice, acting in a way in which it understands to be a correct interpretation of the Australian taxation law. There has not been one whisper from the government or the tax office or anybody else that the company's interpretation is somehow wrong. In making that interpretation the company has passed on the benefits—it has not kept them—to a quarter of a million policyholders.

Yet we have the government come in here and say, `We don't agree that was the interpretation of the legislation. We're just going to turn it around now.' In effect, the government is saying, `We don't give a damn about the consequences for the company, for any understanding of correct interpretation of the legislation or, for that matter, for those persons to whom this benefit has been passed on.' If there is an example of retrospectivity at work, then clearly this is it. It ought not be accepted by the parliament and it ought not be accepted by the people of Australia. The amendment which we propose to move in relation to this matter ought to be adopted by the government out of a sense of fairness, which it runs around the country telling people it is in favour of.

The second aspect in relation to the franking dividend imputation is the denial of franking credits where a life company holds shares indirectly through a partnership or trust in a statutory fund that has as its income wholly or partially exempt income. Again, the Life Investment and Superannuation Association of Australia has raised concerns in relation to this matter.

In summary, the deficiency concerned the denial of full franking rebates in circumstances where a life company holds shares indirectly through a partnership or trust in a statutory fund that has its income wholly or partially exempt from tax. An amendment is required to ensure that the policy embodied in subsection 160AQU(2) is given effect to in section 160AQZA.

What is required is an amendment which provides that for the purposes of calculating the rebate of tax, to which a taxpayer is entitled under section 160AQZA, the definitions of potential rebate amount and trust amount should be interpreted for the purposes of section 160AQZA by disregarding sections such as 110C, 112A, 116FB and so on. Again, there are problems in relation to this particular section which we believe the government ought to address. The government should not leave these anomalies simply hanging in the wind, as it does as a consequence of this bill.

The third area that we have concerns about relates to franking credits and international profit misallocation. The bill amends part IIIA to provide that no franking credits arise under the imputation system for tax paid by companies where a payment of tax is made in relation to profits which have been misallocated offshore through transfer pricing or non-arms-length dealings. The amendments will apply to original amended assessments which issue after the budget announcement on 9 May 1995, irrespective of the income year to which the misallocation of profit adjustments arises. Again, concerns have been raised by a number of bodies in relation to this.

The Institute of Chartered Accountants has argued that the provision will damage Australia's export earnings. It makes the point that there is little agreement between the Australian Taxation Office and tax advisers on transfer pricing, which is the dominant issue in international trade. A recent media release from the Institute of Chartered Accountants in which they address this issue states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Director at the Institute, Ian Langford-Brown, said the decision denying franking credits for tax paid by companies on transfer pricing adjustments, which was announced in the Budget, would damage Australia's export earnings.

"Considering there is little agreement between the Tax Office and tax advisers on this contentious problem, which is the dominant issue in international trade, the changes the Government has made are unbelievable," Mr Langford-Brown said.
He goes on to explain his contention. He says:
"Taxpayers are facing loaded dice on this issue, especially as the National Tax Liaison Group is still far from agreement on such fundamentals as methodologies, comparatives, and so on.

Mr Langford-Brown said the new rules on transfer pricing were at odds with the principle that the level of penalties directly relates to whether the adjustment arose from a deliberate act or an inadvertent error.

"Auditors and company directors now face further uncertainties in forming a view on a company's accounts and businesses face further confusion over how the change will be implemented by the Tax Office.

The matter was also raised by the Corporate Tax Association. It says that the proposal will impact unfairly in many cases, especially for Australian multinationals. The new legislation seeks to trace the relevant profits but it can be seen for an Australian group that any profits misallocated would still remain within the group for later distribution and there can be no justification for the denial of the franking credits.

PARA.TAB: We also have concerns in relation to the provisions relating to research and development. Research and development syndicates have been a mechanism for funding research and development by companies requiring taxation shelter. Generally these companies would not spend money on research and development in the absence of the deduction.

On the other hand, companies which wish to conduct research and development need funds and cannot make use of a tax deduction. A significant source of these projects has come from private and public tax exempt companies. The amendments are aimed at ensuring that consistent tax treatment is afforded to expenditure, as is the case with expenditure incurred by public tax exempt entities under section 73CB.

The amendments apply to expenditure incurred after 7.30 p.m. on 9 May when the measure was announced. The transitional rules are slightly more generous than the original transitional rules announced on 9 May. However, in 1992 the government moved to deny a deduction for research and development to syndicates involving public sector tax exempt bodies by the insertion of section 73CB into the act. A Senate amendment introduced a transitional measure.

A number of allegations have been made by private sector tax exempt researchers who do not fall within the transitional arrangements as applications were lodged prior to 9 May but had not been considered by the Research and Development Board. For example, one researcher alleges that they were led by AusIndustry to believe that their submissions would be considered at the board meeting in June. Another alleges that AusIndustry officials advised all the major syndicate arrangers during the lead-up to the May meeting that private tax exempt syndicates would not be considered at the May meeting but the deferral would not affect their right to consideration at a later meeting. Other private tax exempt applications were considered at the May meeting and improved.

For example, one of the submissions is from the Victor Chang Cardiac Research Institute at St Vincent's Hospital in Sydney. If there were a worthy research institute in Australia that ought to be treated with equality by the government in the way in which it treats such funds, I could not think of one better deserving of that than the Victor Chang Cardiac Research Institute at St Vincent's Hospital in Sydney. But the institute points out that the effect of this bill is that, even though it submitted a research and development syndicate application on 3 May 1995 in accordance with the legislation existing before 9 May 1995, it would not be considered. The institute goes on to point out the unfairness of that situation.

There are other submissions which relate to this matter, some of which I cannot name because of aspects of commercial confidentiality that arise. But they clearly indicate, as I have indicated in general terms, that companies were given an assurance—that is, provided that their application had been lodged before the date, even with the application having not been considered, that any subsequent consideration of it would bring them within the provisions. Now we have legislation which indicates that that is not the case. For those reasons, we will be moving amendments to allow the old provisions to continue to apply to those applications which were lodged prior to the budget announcement.

There are a couple of other matters in this bill which I will just briefly touch upon, as time is expiring. The provision relating to the sales tax exemption for rice milk reflects matters which were raised in a private member's bill by Senator Watson earlier this year. For that reason, we are delighted that the government has picked that provision up.

Also, there are some provisions which relate to horticulture which I just wish to touch on very briefly. These are the tax write-off provisions for new horticulture plantations. The bill inserts division 10F to implement the budget announcement concerning new horticultural plantations to allow for the write-off of the original capital expenditure incurred in establishing horticultural plants used in the business of primary production. The provisions apply to each horticultural plant. To claim a write-off, the taxpayer must own the plants and use the plants to produce assessable income from a business of horticulture. Lessees and licensees who carry on the business of horticulture will be entitled to the deduction in preference to the lessor or licenser.

The amendments apply to expenditure incurred after 9 May in establishing horticultural plants. It is interesting that the bill implements the government's belated response to the 2000 horticultural task force which recommended in February 1994 that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Industry Commission recommendation that the taxation treatment of expenditure on all new horticultural plantations be revised to provide a more neutral treatment compared with expenditure on other activities. All new horticultural plantings should be treated consistently with the recent government amendments to the ITAA to allow the costs of acquisition and planting of grapevines to be written off over four years from the time of planting.

The task force was essentially an industry working group, but it was headed by Senator Sherry. On 29 November the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and Senator Bob Collins announced that the government had agreed to the extension of a taxation write-off for expenditure on all new horticultural plantations. The taxation treatment being offered to horticultural plantations is substantially different from that being offered for the cost of establishing grapevines, announced in the 1993 budget as part of the package including sales tax increases. Therefore, some sectors of the horticultural industry have expressed disappointment with the government's proposal and seek the same taxation treatment as that given to grapevines. The wine growers industry, for example, also favours consistent treatment being offered to horticultural plantations.

PARA.TAB: There are problems that arise out of the different way in which the treatment applies to horticulture as it does to grapes, some of which are of a technical nature which time precludes me at present from going into. I can say though that, as far as the coalition is concerned, the recommendations of the Industry Commission are those which we support and, in government, are matters which we would attend to. We are disappointed that they have not been dealt with either in a timely manner or effectively by this government in this particular bill when it had the opportunity to do so.

In conclusion, there are many other matters in this complex and complicated piece of taxation legislation arising from this year's budget announcements which time precludes me from addressing. Suffice it to say that we will not be opposing the bill as a whole or those various other measures. But we do have concerns about three matters in particular which I have raised, and in the committee stage of this bill we will be moving amendments accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to contribute to the debate on the bills which are before the House tonight. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995, as outlined in the second reading speech by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), is a package of innovative measures designed to contribute to the overriding principal objective of the 1995-96 budget—that is, to provide for the continued expansion of the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: The raft of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which stem from the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) covers a very wide range of issues that have already been covered here today. To this end, I will concentrate on just a few of the key amendments in order to highlight the contribution they will make to this government's budget objective of economic expansion.

I think you will agree, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this government's economic management record since its election in 1983 is second to none. Indeed, the government over the past 12 1/2 years has transformed this nation's economy from a non-competitive and insular backwater into one that is highly competitive and fully integrated into the global economy.

Australia over the past two years has seen a remarkable economic recovery take place in the wake of a worldwide recession in the early 1990s, thanks to this government's responsible economic management. The economy, after surging in 1994 with a growth rate of five per cent, is now at a more sustainable level approaching 3.75 per cent. Complementing these sustainable growth figures, the underlying inflation rate remains at about 2.5 per cent and employment growth continues apace, with tens of thousands of jobs being created on a monthly basis under the Working Nation employment strategy. As a result, interest rates, while stable at the moment, are being predicted to fall, thus providing a further boost to the economy.

On the subject of unemployment or, more specifically, employment and the role that Working Nation is playing there, I would put on record my thanks for the contribution that many people are making in our communities right throughout Australia, particularly some in my own electorate, in ensuring the success of Working Nation. We make all those decisions here, and rightly so. But they must filter down through the community to be assured of success there. The area consultative committee in my electorate has played a vital role in the success of the Working Nation initiatives there. I thank all those who are participating on that committee for its success and the way that success is flowing on to our local community.

Business investment and profitability have been buoyant, with investment expenditure outstripping budget forecasts and retail turnover figures for 1995-96 being over and above the impressive 7.5 per cent increase of 1994-95 thus far. There is a lot of good news about economic growth and prosperity in Australia at the current time. It is something that I believe should be focused on a lot more.

No-one can deny that particular growth, despite the efforts of the chicken littles on the opposition front bench—that is, the member for Higgins (Mr Costello) and the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)—who are more intent on scaremongering than on getting behind and promoting Australian economic growth and prosperity. That is what we need to do to ensure the confidence necessary out in our community for business to expand—and that is, of course, where the jobs are.

Whilst the figures indicate that the economy is growing apace, the government recognises that there is still much work to be done in maintaining our growth rate and increasing employment growth and national living standards. The budget this year, delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Willis), certainly recognised this point and, in response, has put in place a legislative framework to increase public savings and private savings to ensure long-term economic growth in Australia.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995 forms a key component of the government's strategy to tighten fiscal policy and deliver on our budget commitment to reduce the federal government's call on private savings and, in so doing, increase the budget surplus from $718 million in 1995-96 to approximately $7.4 billion or 1.2 per cent of gross domestic product in 1998-99.The revenue measures that the government is putting in place through the taxation amendment bills, including the one before the House today, will strengthen the Commonwealth's tax base, which has been in decline as a share of GDP since 1987-88, by adding an estimated $2.4 billion to revenue in 1995-96 and $3.6 billion in 1996-97.

With the tightening and removing of anomalies to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as part of this strategy, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995 will put in place key technical changes relating to the levelling of capital gains tax, dividend imputations and franking credits to this effect. In relation to part IIIAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, this amendment bill will ensure that franking credits in certain circumstances cannot be used to largely negate the additional company tax payable as a result of an adjustment to reflect arms-length dealings where profits have been shifted or misallocated offshore.

In this context, the proposed amendment will provide that no franking credits arise when a payment of tax is made in relation to a misallocation of profit adjustment. Similarly, if a misallocation of profit is subsequently reduced upon appeal, objection or review, a franking credit will not arise upon the issue of an amended assessment.

As such, the potential to deliberately avoid paying company tax or inadvertently avoid paying company tax on these types of transactions will be negated, with only a slight increase in compliance costs to those companies which have already misallocated or shifted profits offshore. Consequently, the estimated gains to revenue from this measure are $3 million in 1994-95, $21 million in 1995-96 and $25 million in subsequent years.

Like the amendment dealing with franking credits, the changes to the dividend imputation provisions under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 will also correct franking related problems primarily associated with mutual and non-mutual life insurance companies. On the subject of dividend imputation, I must say that this was another initiative of this government. We assisted to expand industry and give it more opportunities to take advantage of such incentives. It is one of the many things that this government has helped to progress with the many reforms we have undertaken.

More importantly, the amendment puts in place the legislative framework requiring companies to establish a class C franking account recording franking credits and debits and the distribution of imputation credits to shareholders. That follows the increase in the company tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent. The government, in increasing the company tax rate to 36 per cent, thought it appropriate that the corporate sector—whose profit share has returned to the record levels of the 1980s—make a contribution to the tightening of fiscal policy, thus benefiting all Australians in the long term. Of course, that is very much to the heart of the equity question underpinning this government's taxation reforms. To this end, the increase in the company tax rate will add an extra $320 million to revenue in 1995-96 and an estimated $1.57 billion in 1996-97.

In relation to the operation of the capital gains tax provisions under division 19A of part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, this bill seeks to make a number of amendments, the chief purpose being to reduce compliance costs on corporate tax payers and ensure that division 19A is not a disincentive to corporate restructuring. As members of the House will recall, division 19A operates to prevent timing advantages that could arise when assets are transferred and values are shifted between shares and loans in commonly owned transferor and transferee companies.

In this context, the major amendments to the act will include: the introduction of anti-avoidance measures so that cost base adjustments will be made to shares or loans in a company in respect of newly created assets which are vested in a related company; simplifying the tests used to determine whether a value shift has occurred when an asset that was acquired by a commonly owned company, before it came to be under common ownership with the transferee company, is transferred to another group or company; the insertion of new rules to be applied in determining when a value shift will be taken to have occurred as a consequence of the transfer of a depreciable asset between commonly owned companies; and the modification and extension of the current tests used to determine whether a value shift has occurred, recognising situations where interests in the transferor are held by more than one member of the company group.

The amendments I have just outlined from the bill before the House today—besides contributing to the government's strategy to promote economic growth through a fiscal tightening—highlight the simple fact that, since we came to government in 1983, we have built a much more effective, efficient and fairer taxation system by a long shot than we had under the previous coalition government. Indeed, this government in 1983 inherited a ramshackle tax system which was riddled with loopholes that defied description. You could have driven the proverbial semitrailer through the legislation and not have been caught if you were not paying your fair share of tax.

Our tax system at that point was the laughing stock of the Western world. In that context, the honourable member for Bennelong, as Treasurer, basically condoned a system where paying tax was optional for the wealthiest people in this country. It was optional: you could have decided whether you wanted to pay tax or not, and you do not need any guesses to work out which course someone like that would take. As was pointed out by the royal commissioner, the bottom-of-the-harbour rorts under the Fraser government saw the fastest growing industry in Australia at the time, being the tax avoidance industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill and the Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Amendment Bill were introduced into the House of Representatives on 28 September 1995. It is worth noting that all but one of the measures contained in these cognate bills were announced in the budget of 9 May 1995. It is also worth noting that that was 3 1/2 months before the bills were introduced into this chamber and some 4 1/2 months before the parliament began consideration prior to passing a bill in amended form. In those circumstances, it is good to see that the government has finally thought it appropriate to bring the proposed legislation before the parliament so that the full detail of the measures can be seen and so that we will finally get to talk about them.

PARA.TAB: The bill amends three principal acts: the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1993. The bill is written in the new style adopted as part of the tax law improvement project which is conveniently known as TLIP—it is almost `tulip'. It is supposed to use a simpler form of language and the numbering system is different. The stated aim is to have a simpler law which is easier to comply with. I believe the bill fails on this count. It fails to meet the objectives of the TLIP.

The bills deal with 11 different matters and amount to a total of 205 pages of amendments. Schedule 7 alone, which deals with trust losses, amounts to 55 pages. It is therefore little wonder that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is considered by anyone who has had the opportunity to have a look at it to be extremely complex. But why should these amendments be so paper consuming and complex? The answer is the policy which underlines the legislation. As the Australian Taxation Institute has stated, this legislation applies differing rules depending on the category of trust being dealt with. This is contrasted with sections 80A to 80E, under which loss recoupment rules are applied to companies and which are relatively simple to understand and to comply with. The institute has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For this reason, it is submitted that the cost of compliance with these new rules will far exceed those in relation to the company loss provisions and for this reason alone, the TIA is critical of their present format.

The government pays lip-service to reducing the cost of compliance but, because it is unable to get its policy framework in good order, the end result is invariably further increases in compliance costs. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) deals with capital gains tax amendments relating to value shifting and other general amendments, dividend imputation, franking credits and international profit misallocation, demutualisation of insurance companies, and establishment costs of horticultural plants. It also proposes changes to the tax treatment of forestry plantations, research and development, sales tax exemption for rice milk, trust losses, and non-compulsory uniforms or wardrobes. I propose to deal with only some of these matters because of limited speaking time, although I hope to comment on others when the bills are considered in the consideration in detail stage.

PARA.TAB: The government has circulated amendments to this bill before we have even deliberated on it. So the comments I make relate to the bill as it was first introduced. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) said in his second reading speech that a supplementary explanatory memorandum was available with the proposed amendments. I simply record that it was not available, but I also acknowledge with gratitude that the Assistant Treasurer obtained a copy for me because I made it known to him at the time that he was wrong.

Part 1 of schedule 7 inserts a new schedule 2C into the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide new rules that have to be satisfied by trusts before prior and current year losses can be deducted. The proposed rules, with the exception of an income injection test, will not apply to family trusts. The rules that will apply, other than the income injection test, will depend on the type of trust being considered.

The bill distinguishes between three basic types of trusts: fixed trusts, including widely held unit trusts; non-fixed trusts; and excepted trusts. The new regime will contain an income injection test which applies to deny a deduction to the trust for losses. The explanatory memorandum accompanying the bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: In broad terms, the test will apply where, in connection with a scheme, the losses are used to shelter assessable income from tax.
Several problems have been highlighted by the Australian Taxation Institute and the Australian Society of Chartered Practising Accountants.

PARA.TAB: The `continuity of business test' differentiates between the rules relating to companies and those for trusts. The differentiation places fixed trusts at a tax disadvantage compared with companies, and I have already touched on that. These new rules will restrict the circumstances in which current and prior year losses can be deducted. On 6 October, Mr Terry Rooney of the ASCPA said:

SPEECH.PARA: The new rules regarding the utilisation of losses generated by trusts are especially harsh and represent the greatest change to the taxation of trusts in the past 10 years.

In the budget, the Treasurer announced that he intended to stop the leakage of revenue through trafficking in trust losses, but in typical government over zealousness the changes go too far and will dry up the economic reservoir for many businesses.

It seems the government's attitude to trusts is that they are created only to avoid and/or reduce tax obligations. The fact is that tax is only one factor in the creation of trusts. With the income injection test, the proposed rules are overly prescriptive, making the law more complex than it need be and also failing to take into account circumstances other than those catered for in the bill.

PARA.TAB: In these instances, such as the `different amount of assessable income' and the definition of the concept of `benefit', it would have been better if the government had used some sort of anti-avoidance clause. Such a clause would ensure that the intent of the legislation—that is, the targeting of trafficking in trust losses and therefore tax avoidance—is actually achieved without hindering trusts which are not engaged in avoiding tax obligations.

Concerns have also been raised about the definition of the family trust. Naturally, existing family trusts would not want to be reclassified as a non-fixed trust and thereby have to meet all four tests to be applied. This is something which should be examined to ensure that legitimate family trusts are not deprived of their status.
As to franking credits and international profit misallocation, this bill, as claimed in the explanatory memorandum:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will provide that no franking credits arise where a payment of tax is made in relation to a misallocation of profit adjustment.

Similarly, where a misallocation of profit adjustment is subsequently reduced (eg. upon objection, review, or appeal), a franking debit will not arise upon the issue of an amended assessment where the payment of tax for the original misallocation of profit adjustment did not give rise to a franking credit.

This is a measure which the Corporate Tax Association and tax practitioners generally have raised serious concerns about. It is opposed by them because it is seen as being too harsh. As well as there being the proposals in this bill, the Australian Taxation Office has issued two tax rulings, TR94/14 and TR95/D11, which, together, are almost 200 pages. PARA.TAB: The problem with the Australian Taxation Office's policy and approach generally is that there is no reasonableness test. Their interpretation of the law is clearly aimed at maximising revenue to the detriment of applying the law in the way originally intended. The ATO maintains that, where a taxpayer calculates the amount of tax payable in a different way from the ATO, the ATO is entitled to impose penalties. This is compounded by this bill should an unintentional underpayment of tax occur, because not only will the taxpayer be subject to penalties but the amount of tax paid will not give rise to imputation credits when calculating the credits for company tax paid upon a dividend being declared by a taxpayer company. The proposed changes are unfair and will no doubt lead to increased litigation.

The reason for this probable development is obvious: taxpayers are less likely to accept such patently unfair rulings. After all, tax rulings are not law but simply a guide as to how the ATO interprets the law. The ATO can and does make mistakes, as we and taxpayers know only too well. This has been borne out by several legal cases where tax rulings have been challenged and struck down by the courts. The measures in this bill and the tax rulings as well need to be reassessed so as not to introduce patently unfair practices into the tax law.

The amendments contained in part 2 of schedule 4 relate to forestry plantations. This amendment will ensure that, where a taxpayer who conducts timber operations purchases an established forest or plantation before the trees are felled, the taxpayer pays tax on only the net proceeds from the sale of the trees. I endorse this amendment, and I make it clear that I strongly support measures to encourage the move towards forestry plantations.

The fact is that the most obvious solution to the current problems of woodchipping native forest is to harvest new-growth plantation forests. This will reduce the need to harvest old-growth forests, in which so much of our treasured flora and fauna exist. This particular amendment will supplement the objective set out in the national forest policy statement of 1992, which has been signed by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and all premiers and chief ministers. Article 4.5 in that statement asserts that all Australian governments will continue to encourage plantations. The third paragraph of article 4.5 states:

SPEECH.PARA: To achieve the government's objectives it will be necessary to ensure the impediments to plantation development are minimal in areas such as taxation, planning and access to information.
The government's response to this admirable objective so far has been mixed. Unfortunately, the good intentions are there, yet in terms of tax policy the ATO has tended to make a bit of a mess of it.

PARA.TAB: The major problem relates to the management of tax rulings by the Australian Taxation Office. As I mentioned in this place I think on 1 March of this year, the Australian Taxation Office now refuses to provide private tax rulings for afforestation projects. I understand that the reason for the ATO not issuing a private ruling is that they refuse to provide these in relation to primary industry production projects as a curious matter of course.

It is harebrained action such as that which has the potential to cripple moves towards plantation and renewable sources of timber. Companies developing plantations need to know with some certainty how they will be taxed on future earnings. The only positive development in this area is that the ATO has finally completed its review of tax ruling IT360 and replaced it in May with the new ruling TR95/6.

More can be done by the government, however, to encourage plantation developments. I draw the House's attention to the excellent coalition policy paper entitled `Degradation in Australia', which was launched by the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) earlier this year. Within this document is a commitment to the reafforestation of 15 per cent of Australia's cleared land, with incentives to be provided to landowners to reach that objective. This will no doubt include tax concessions for seeds and seedlings, fencing and the like.

With newly reafforested land there should be plenty of scope for plantations. The problems we have in terms of forestry policy are that we have a government which sends out mixed signals and we have some extremists in the environmentalist camp who are totally opposed to the woodchipping of any forests, including plantations. It is through the development of plantations on currently cleared land that we can begin to rectify many land degradation problems such as salinity and erosion.

Plantations also provide an economically sustainable method of doing our bit to reverse the greenhouse effect. We need a unified policy approach and the right incentives. To this end, we should re-examine the method by which plantation income is treated for tax purposes. One suggested way of accounting for the expenses and revenue of plantation forests would be to deduct the total of real expenses from revenue at the time of the sale of the timber which generates the taxable income.

One of the problems for the plantation industry is that it incurs a great deal of expense over many years prior to being able to harvest the timber. This results in massive taxable income in the financial years when harvesting occurs. It might be better for all expenses relating to a plantation to be maintained in real terms and deducted in the year in which the income is received. I emphasise that this is only one suggestion about how the tax treatment of plantations might evolve.

Plantations Australia—that is the industry organisation—has mentioned five additional measures for reforming the tax system to encourage plantation development. The objective is simple: we need a tax regime for plantations which not only encourages investment but also avoids the creation of artificial tax havens. Incentives should be offered only where the industry is stagnating. Eliminating taxation problems, however, should be sufficient to encourage plantation forests. (Time expired)
