In this budget there is a debt of $9 billion to pay the interest charges on borrowings of the Commonwealth. That is almost as much as the health budget and it is as much as the defence and education budgets. This is a government out borrowing money.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Ms Crawford), who is at the table, has gone quiet because she cannot confront the facts. She knows what will happen in her electorate and other electorates around Australia: the Australian people will have a chance to have a say on what they feel about this avaricious government which wants to consume more and more of the gross domestic product by personal taxation and which at the same time wants to borrow so much that it is going to put into hock generation after generation of Australians.

The fact is that the combination of bracket creep and other factors, including a tighter tax compliance net, has allowed the Labor Party to collect more and more taxation. They are big taxing. They are the largest taxing government. It does not matter that they have reduced the top marginal rate. The fact is that those on twice average weekly earnings are paying more now than they were before. The ones who are most hit—the ones who are paying the greatest increase of their income in increased taxation—are those on average weekly earnings. It is the very group that 10 years ago the Prime Minister said he stood for and for whom he would make changes to benefit. They are the ones who are suffering the most under this current tax regime.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) adds to tax law in a myriad of ways. It is almost incomprehensible to take in all the various charges and changes. Accountancy firms tell me that they charge a minimum fee of $5,000 to give advice on the capital gains taxation assessments and tell you whether you are eligible for capital gains tax. These are small shopkeepers who do not know how to make decisions on whether they should buy or sell or what they should do with their small businesses. We have large accounting firms growing fat. The government is putting money in the pockets of lawyers and accountants, but not enough in the pockets of those who are productive and making the tax that you want to charge them and making the profits that are necessary to employ people.

The capital gains tax in this legislation proposes increases in personal use thresholds and changes to the anti-avoidance rules for assets, amendments to the value shifting rules of division 19A of part IIIA, compulsory roll-over of capital losses on group transfers of assets, exclusion of assets used to produce income subject to withholding tax from the capital gains tax and exemption for assets producing exempt income. There is a nice little mouthful. One can go through the legislation and see the complexity of the changes. It includes changes of dividend imputation charges, tax write-off for capital costs of establishing new horticultural plants, treatment of the sale of immature forestry plantations and transfer responsibility for the maintenance of the register of approved occupational clothing. I do not know how people follow the changes that we make. It also includes demutualisation of insurance companies, measures to prevent trafficking in trust losses and clarification of application of the capital gains tax to taxable Australian assets. All of these amendments are contained in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4).

I have outlined the disastrous record of the Keating government in regard to personal income tax. I have highlighted the fact that when the Keating reforms were unveiled 10 years ago they were heralded as an approach to slashing marginal tax rates. They have done nothing of the sort. Marginal tax rates are lower, but people are paying more personal tax than they were 10 years ago. One has to bear on top of that the sorts of attitudes of the Prime Minister himself because it is very difficult to know exactly what the Prime Minister stands for. On the one hand, he is the one who promised l-a-w law tax cuts but, on the other hand, he broke his promise and increased sales tax at the same time.

It is very hard to know which Prime Minister is actually the Prime Minister one should vote for—whether it is the one who promised l-a-w law cuts before an election or the one who increased sales tax after an election. Is it the Prime Minister who promised never ever to increase the Medicare levy? He said that this was just going to be sacrosanct and it would pay for the medical treatment of Australians for the next 100 years on one per cent or 1.5 per cent, but it would never increase. Does one vote for or support the Prime Minister who said he is not going to increase the Medicare levy but who then did increase it? One does not know where one stands. It depends on whether it is before or after an election. The question that needs to be asked is: which Paul Keating would you vote for?

What about the promised company tax cuts? They were reduced for a year or two and then they were put back up again. One would not know whether those company tax commitments are real or not. Where do you make the assessment on whether or not something is going to stay there or something will be removed or whether something is going to be a great initiative on marginal tax to reduce taxation for the middle income earners? The facts are proven. Even over a 10-year period, when there should have been a substantial period of test, there is a greater proportion of gross domestic product being collected in personal income tax and the middle income earners of Australia are worse off. They are paying a greater proportion of their income in taxation than they have ever paid before.

Does one go to other areas to decide which aspect of the Prime Minister's character or promise one should really accept? Which Paul Keating should one vote for? The Prime Minister promised to remove the age pension from the income tax area. It has not happened. I cannot understand the Australian Labor Party being so blase in breaking promises of that sort. What about the Prime Minister who promised to reduce the foreign debt? I think that ran for around four or five budgets. We even had a budget which was self-repairing in regard to the foreign debt. I think Mr Dawkins introduced that one. It never self-repaired; it only got worse. The fact is that the Prime Minister has now raised the foreign debt to record levels after promising to reduce it.

Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) fits in the vein of all previous tax bills that have been before this House. It is complex and it increases taxation. It will not be opposed by the coalition, but we in despair ask: which Prime Minister can you really trust or vote for? Can you trust one who 10 years ago said he would reduce the rate of marginal taxation and reduce the amount paid by middle income earners if, 10 years later, you find that you are paying more? Or is it the Prime Minister who promised l-a-w law tax cuts and then broke his promise and increased taxation by way of sales tax? One does not know.

It is with despair that the Australian people look at what is going on here in the Australian parliament. Much of this legislation, except for compliance areas, is not needed. Much of it adds to the complexity and cost of compliance. Much of it does not do anything to increase productivity or production, profitability, jobs or contentment in the Australian community. The Australian community knows it. The government does not recognise it. The people will have their chance at the next election, which I believe will be held quite soon, to say to the Prime Minister, `The time you've had is long enough. We no longer believe you because we don't know which Paul Keating we can believe.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) on his contribution to this debate. Unlike him, I will concentrate in my remarks on the horticultural implications of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis, you would know, because members of your family are fortunate enough to live in the beautiful electorate of Cowper, that we are blessed with production of a wide range of horticultural products. While Cowper is perhaps most notable for bananas, we also produce large quantities of blueberries, avocados, pawpaws, macadamias, kiwi fruit, low chill stone fruits, citrus and so on. And that is just to mention a few. Obviously there will be a great deal of interest within my electorate in the implications of the bill.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that I take the opportunity to speak up on behalf of the horticulturalists of the north coast of New South Wales. There are other members to the north of me who should be here speaking about them and advocating for them. The honourable member for Page (Mr Woods) and the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) do not tend to speak very often about the needs of their constituents and the horticultural industry, and that is a great pity.

The bill introduces a new division 10F which is designed to implement the budget announcement concerning new horticultural plantations to allow for the write-off of the original capital expenditure incurred in establishing horticultural plants used in the business of primary production. The provisions apply to each horticultural plant. I applaud the government for bringing this in. As always, I have to be fair dinkum and, if they are doing something that is right or down the track of being right, or an improvement, I have to say so. This is an improvement, although I believe it does not go far enough. I will expand on that. I have to be fair and congratulate the government on seeking to do something better, but there is more to be done.

Horticulture includes the cultivation and propagation of plants, fungi, bulbs, spores and so on, but it does not include the cropping of annual plants or forestry operations. If I have time I will return to this particular definition of horticulture, because it is interesting to see precisely how it is defined in the act. The establishment costs must be capital in nature and not otherwise deductible. The establishment costs do not include the cost of clearing of land or costs that are recouped. Again, if there is time I will expand on that issue.

To claim the write-off, the taxpayer must own the plants and use the plants to produce assessable income from a business or horticulture. Lessees and licensees—because this applies to those who lease land, whether it be crown land or whether they have licences to operate leases elsewhere—are able to carry on the business of horticulture and will be entitled to the deduction in preference to the lessor or licensor.

The write-off begins when the plants are used or held ready for use to produce assessable income. In terms of the bill, this is usually at the beginning of what is expected to be the plant's first commercial season. Herein I believe lies a degree of inequity and injustice. I will expand on this in a moment. The costs are written off over the effective life of the plant and the effective life is measured by its capacity to produce assessable income whilst being used in the business of horticulture. This relates to commercial circumstances rather than botanical possibilities. Of course, the taxpayer can elect to adopt the commissioner's estimates of effective life.

The write-off rates are identical to those for plant and equipment. As an example, if there is less than three years of effective life, there is an immediate write-off; if the effective life is five years to less than 6 2/3, there is a 0.27 write-off, with a maximum write-off period of three years and 257 days. In the case of horticultural trees, which have an effective life of 30 years or more, the prime cost rate is 0.07 and the maximum write-off period is 14 years and 105 days.

If a plant happens to be destroyed by drought, fire or something of that nature, a deduction will be available for the balance of the write-off less any recouped amounts such as insurance. The amendments apply to expenditure incurred after 9 May, the date of the budget. This is expenditure incurred after 9 May in establishing horticultural plants.

I believe we could be much fairer about this, bearing in mind the fact that in many cases horticultural plants have a long lead time before getting to that effective life. It could take five, six or even seven years before you start to get full production from a plant or tree. Therefore, I believe it would be worth while to consider—I will certainly urge it on the coalition government which will be in power after the next election—amending this so the concession can apply to expenditure already incurred for plants that are about to commence their effective life.

In other words, if this measure came in on 9 May and the plants were to produce their effective life in the coming spring or summer season, I suggest the effective date should be retrospective to the expenditure when they started to come in. Obviously there has to be a limit and you cannot go back forever. In the current financial year the horticulturalists will be taxed on the income produced from plants and trees that are bearing this year for the first time, and they will have no benefit whatsoever from all the capital costs put into the establishment before they become productive. I believe that would be a fair variation to make.

Currently there is no write-off available for the capital cost of establishing or acquiring live plants which crop more than once in a plant's life and that is unfair. However, the cost of planting annual crops such as wheat and barley is deductible at the time the expenditure is incurred, because the production cycle is annual and the expenditure on grain for planting is considered recurrent. Accordingly, the government has decided to remove this discrimination and provide appropriate tax relief. Again I say publicly that I applaud it for taking this action.

It has been suggested that the Australian Commissioner of Taxation will be issuing a ruling to set out the effective life of different horticultural varieties and individual taxpayers, if they wish, can object to the commissioner's ruling on this. If they can provide the evidence, it may be possible to set a different rate. In actual fact, what this bill is doing is implementing the government's very belated response to the 2000 horticulture task force which as far back as February 1994 recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Industry Commission recommends that the taxation treatment of expenditure on all new horticultural plantations be revised to provide a more neutral treatment compared with expenditure on other activities. All new horticultural planting should be treated consistently with the recent government amendments to the ITAA to allow the costs of acquisition and planting of grapevines to be written off over four years from the time of planting.

That task force was essentially an industry group but was chaired by Senator Sherry. The significant point is that wine growers are able to write off the establishment costs of their vines over four years. I believe, and the coalition believes, that the same provision should be available to other horticultural products.

PARA.TAB: When you are talking about horticultural production, what is the real difference between a grape vine and a kiwi fruit vine? Both need trellises. Grape growers are able to write off their trellises totally over four years. Kiwi fruit growers are not. That is inconsistent. It is an anomaly which I hope will be addressed.

The taxation treatment being offered for horticultural plantations is substantially different from that offered with respect to the cost of establishing grape vines, as announced in the 1993 budget as part of the package which included sales tax increases. Some sectors of the horticultural industry are extremely disappointed—rightly so—with the government's proposal and seek the same taxation treatment as grape vine growers.

To give them great credit, the wine growing industry also favours consistent treatment being offered to all horticultural plantations. I make the point again that if you put in trellises for grapes you get one treatment from the Taxation Office; if you put in trellises for kiwi fruit, you get another. It is not fair.

A number of problems arise from the government's proposal. One is that the tax treatment for horticultural expenses may create a bias towards investing in vineyards rather than other forms of horticulture—

TALK.START.PARA: —Has created.

—Indeed, it already has created a bias. We are in danger of having investment in horticulture being directed not by market forces, which should be operating, but by the different tax benefits available. This has produced distortions within the industry which should not be allowed to occur.

PARA.TAB: The write-off for horticulture does not commence until production commences which, for certain trees that have an extensive effective life, may not be for five or six years. In such circumstances, a write-off is not available until year five or six and the maximum write-off is over 14 years. It will therefore take some 20 years before the cost of some plantations is written off. Again, compare this with the example of the vineyards where things are all fixed and finished in four years.

The deferred write-off of horticultural plantations imposes cashflow burdens. That impacts more heavily on small producers than on large companies. As you would know from personal experience, Mr Deputy Speaker, in my electorate and on the north coast of New South Wales the banana growers, blueberry growers, pawpaw growers and kiwi fruit growers are all small producers. Basically, these are family activities. These people desperately need their cashflow and it would be most beneficial if we were able to change things to give them that benefit. There are also significant compliance cost issues associated with establishing effective lives, especially for audit purposes, given the changes in market requirements and product variation within one fruit type.

We in the coalition support the recommendations of the Industry Commission. We publicly pledge to attend to this matter in government. We will not oppose the bill because, as I said, it is an improvement and goes some way along the track.

I said earlier that I would expand on the definition of `horticulture'. I would like to refer to the explanatory memorandum because this matter is significant and people should be aware of what is involved. `Primary production' is defined, for taxation purposes, as being any of several distinct kinds of production. Each of those kinds of production is distinct from any other.

`Horticulture' is defined in subsection 6(1) in terms which include both the cultivation and propagation of plants, fungi, their seeds, bulbs, spores, and the like. Horticulture is apt to include cultivation for such produce as fruits, flowers, foliage or fruiting bodies. It is apt to include propagation, producing like-growing plants and fungi or their seeds, bulbs and spores. It is commonly distinguished from operations such as grain growing, involving the cropping of annual plants.

There is one specific exclusion. Horticulture does not encompass forestry operations which, as defined, broadly include the planting and tending of trees and forests or plantations where the trees are intended for felling, as well as the felling of trees and the transport of trees by the feller to the place where they will be first milled. I pause at this particular point to deal with the implications for forestry plantations.

At present, forestry is an issue that is being impacted upon mightily by the actions of the federal government and the state government of New South Wales. It is particularly interesting that there are provisions in chapter 7 of this bill for tax justice for forestry plantations. The purpose of these particular amendments is to remove an anomaly in the income tax law that may operate to disadvantage taxpayers who purchase an established but immature plantation or immature forest and subsequently sell it with the timber still standing.

At present, these taxpayers may be taxed on the gross profits of the sale of the standing timber. This matter is very relevant because this year the New South Wales state government, led by Mr Bob Carr, has completely halted any logging of the forests, which have been the traditional source of timber for the northern New South Wales timber industry. The New South Wales government has limited plantations and regrowth areas. From the end of September, all logging activity had to go into regrowth or plantations in north-east New South Wales.

That sounds fine but you have to realise that the loggers are being forcibly put into plantations and regrowth areas 10 to 20 years before they should be there. As well as that, the quotas will be reduced by 30 per cent on 1 July next year and that reduction will go to 50 per cent in 1998. The result is that the plantations now being logged are far too small. Loggers are being forced into taking timber 10 to 20 years too early. That is absolutely crazy.

Quite frankly, while it is good to see that the taxation anomaly is being removed, I wonder if there will be enough timber logging operations going on in the next 15 or 20 years to make that removal valid. The timber industry will be killed, not only by the activity of the New South Wales government but by the federal government's 15 per cent reserve. In addition to national parks, state forests and vacant crown land, the government will have to take 88,800 hectares of freehold land to make up that 15 per cent reserve. The taxation arrangements will be relevant only if people are making money and having to pay tax.

I want to enlarge on the meaning of establishment expenditure. In respect of horticultural plants, establishment expenditure is capital expenditure incurred by a person after 9 May 1995 on the establishment of horticultural plants for use in the business of primary production. There is no definition of what constitutes the cost of establishing a horticultural plantation; however, costs may include the cost of acquiring the plants or their seeds and the cost of planting the plants or seeds.

Costs may also include any costs incurred in preparing to plant—although that does not include the costs of the initial clearing of the land—and, in some cases, part of the costs of ploughing, contouring, top dressing, fertilising, stain removal, top soil enhancement, and so on, which are attributable to the establishment of the plants. They may also include: the cost of pots and potting mixtures for potted plants; the costs incurred in grafting trees; and the cost of replacing existing plants and trees because of the loss of fair economic return due to declining popularity of a particular existing variety.

I have already mentioned trellising and the variation in treatment between kiwi fruit and grape trellises. Netting should also be mentioned. Very often these plants have to be netted. There is capital expenditure in putting up the wiring. I have been involved in putting up netting over blueberries to protect them from birds. It would be fairer for blueberry growers if they could write off that expenditure over four years.

In conclusion, I repeat that the coalition certainly supports this bill. But, while it is a step in the right direction, it does not go far enough. I fully expect that after the next election we will be on the treasury bench and I look forward then to being able to do the right thing by the horticultural producers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), particularly after the remarks made by the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) because they provide an appropriate backdrop to the comments that I would like to make on this bill. As the member for Cowper has said, the particular interest that he and I have, and I am bold to suggest that the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) has, in this bill focuses on its implications for horticultural plantings.

PARA.TAB: The government has long been proud of its reputation as a non-interventionist government. It has endeavoured, I believe with good intent, to let market forces find their own course. It has endeavoured to stay out of and not interfere in the marketplace. There have been times when it would have been much easier for the opposition to have criticised the government for that, particularly in such areas as world trade reform, but instead the opposition has chosen, because it believes the government is on the right track, to support the government in its largely non-interventionist role in the market.

The bill we have before us tonight, as elucidated by the member for Cowper, illustrates an area where the government has somewhat unwittingly intervened in and interfered with the marketplace. Following the 1993 Dawkins budget proposal for a wine tax—a tax that was opposed by the opposition and the wine industry—part of the compromise offered to the wine industry, as a package of reforms to get it to accept a review of the tax, was the opportunity for the cost of planting vineyards to be written off over a five-year period.

It is fair to say that, in that instance, the government interfered with, intervened in, the arrangements that were in place for the establishment of vineyards. It intervened, deliberately skewing the tax act in order to encourage the planting of vineyards. In that role, the government was supported by the opposition. As a result, wherever you go in vineyard areas in Australia in 1995 you can see quite an unprecedented growth in vineyard development.

It is particularly marked in my electorate, in the Riverland and the Barossa, and in the Clare Valley of the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin). Those from electorates in New South Wales would be familiar with the dramatic expansion that is occurring in the Hunter, and the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) can vouch for the dramatic expansion that is occurring in the Coonawarra region.

The expansion in grape plantings is unprecedented, and it may be well founded. There is no reason why the House should be nervous about the expansions occurring in the grape industry. In fact, judging by an inquiry last week into the future of the wine-grape industry in Australia, there is every reason to be optimistic. Only last night, along with a number of coalition members, I dined in the House with a winemaker who indicated that he was anticipating a further expansion in his vineyard that would cost about $3.5 million. The only reason he had not proceeded with that expansion was that he was waiting for the outcome of the government's deliberation on the report into the wine industry and the decision as to how the sales tax and the sales tax structure for the wine industry ought to be set up.

The point remains that the government chose to intervene in order to favour the planting of wine grapes. As a result of that, horticulturalists around Australia said, `Why can't we have some of this action as well?' After all, a tree in the ground has much the same life expectancy as a vine in the ground, and a tree in the ground has much the same, although in some cases a somewhat extended, lead time—that is, the time between planting and harvesting. It takes trees about five or six years and vines three or four years.

So it was, after the decision of the government to intervene in the wine industry, that the citrus industry found itself in crisis. There was a call for a review of horticultural plantings across Australia. The government set up a task force under Senator Sherry, and one of the things that that task force offered to the citrus industry principally, but to horticultural industries generally, was a review of the tax write-off on horticultural plantings. The task force suggested that that review should parallel what had happened in the wine industry and what had been done for vineyard plantings across Australia. Horticulturalists were left with a general air of anticipation. They anticipated that the government would legislate so as to allow them the same write-off as existed for viticulturists. What they got was the bill currently before the House.

The problem with this bill is that the government has intervened, with opposition support, and as a consequence it has unwisely prejudiced investment in favour of viticulture. It has run counter to the market forces. It is true to say that, in the present optimistic outlook for wine grapes, we can expect the plantings that are occurring in vineyards, but those who have money to invest, particularly in the irrigation areas—represented here by the member for Mallee and me—are currently encouraged to invest by reason of the tax structure in a vineyard planting rather than a horticultural planting.

The government has to come to terms with the fact that the bill before the House suggests, unwisely, that people should favour vineyards over horticultural plantings not because of the market outlook but because of the opportunity to write off their investments over a much smaller time. The reality is that not the same plants but comparable plants in terms of their life expectancy—not plants with a comparable lead time but plants with a dramatically different tax write-off schedule—are going to the ground as a result of the bill currently being considered.

I am aware better than most, if I may immodestly suggest, of the optimistic outlook that the wine industry currently has. But what we should not overlook are the opportunities for export enhancement that also apply to horticultural industries. You have only to look at the quantity of walnuts, for example, currently being imported into Australia or the quantity of olives coming into Australia to know that here are two crops where Australian producers can match the rest of the world—if only we could encourage Australian producers to invest in these crops, both of which have an extensive lead time and a long life.

It is true that a similar analogy could be used for the almond industry and even the citrus industry, the crisis in which prompted this legislation. Even the citrus industry currently has export potential that was not appreciated 18 months ago. I am aware of a packing house in my region which in a 12-month period has taken its fruit packing line from an average export performance of 15 per cent to 45 per cent. So opportunities are there. What the government should be wary of is deliberately structuring the tax base so that it favours vineyards unfairly over horticultural plantings.

I would encourage the government—and it is the intention of the opposition to deliberately change this legislation when it has the numbers to do so—to ensure that those who choose to plant either vineyards or horticultural crops do so knowing that it is the market that dictates that decision and not a decision of the government to offer a short-term tax write-off.

The bill before the House includes a schedule of the manner in which horticultural crops, horticultural plants, may be written off. That schedule in itself is a reason for us to be apprehensive about the legislation, because it complicates the way in which growers can go about writing off a crop. The reality, as I hope the House is aware, is that under the vineyard legislation—

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Racism is the theory that human characteristics and intellectual abilities are determined by race and that these are hereditary. This belief is one of the lowest and most primitive forms of collectivism. It is the idea that people are judged by the character and actions of their ancestors rather than as individuals. Racists therefore form hostile attitudes and preach superiority based on their perceptions of history. Racism is fed by the `them and us syndrome' and is exacerbated by the degree to which any group of people denies individuality and declares itself different from the rest as a collective.

PARA.TAB: In the 20th century the development of more efficient killing mechanisms, mass media and the unprecedented mobility of the world's population have made possible the worst excesses of racism in human history—the holocaust, apartheid and now the Balkan tragedy. Multiculturalism was created as a solution to the problems of racism. But as the Australian newspaper reported about race relations in the USA:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is a growing chorus of influential voices which argues that multiculturalism, far from being the harbinger of a fairer, more tolerant and more peaceful America, is in fact a turncoat which threatens the very future it was designed to protect.

These voices are not confined, as could be expected, to the reactionary right wing, eager to maintain a dominant white Anglo status quo, but from moderate and even left-of-centre thinkers, many of whom have done an unprecedented about-face.

The problem is that to the extent that multiculturalism promotes tolerance it is a good thing but to the extent that it promotes separatism and hostility it leads back to the gas chambers. Cultural pride is a two-sided coin. To draw comfort from one's ancestors, traditions and group can be good but it also can be the beginning of insanity, as Hitler's promotion of national pride and Aryan culture in the 1930s demonstrated.We are all part of the human race and there are common and universal individual human rights which take precedence over nationalism or cultural sovereignty.

PARA.TAB: Aboriginal policy in Australia over the last 20 years has sometimes veered close to apartheid and separatism. Reinforcement of cultural pride and self-determination taken to extremes contain the seeds of their own failure. It has become commonplace for some Aboriginal leaders to be reported making racist statements about `whitey' and advocating racial separation. They give the impression they would like to press the rewind button and have everyone who has arrived in Australia since 1788 run backwards to Circular Quay and take a ship back to where they came from in a reverse family reunion, boat people program.

Such attitudes can only erode the overwhelming desire of the majority of people to remove the many disadvantages suffered by people of Aboriginal descent. A relatively minor example of such separatism is the closure of some through roads in Australia and the requirement to obtain passes to access others, South African style, based on one's racial origin.

With the enormous growth of tourism in outback Australia this is promoting unnecessary hostile attitudes to Aboriginal people and exacerbating racial tension. No-one disputes the requirement to obtain the landowner's permission to access private roads but the closure of through roads, or the requirement to obtain passes for main connecting roads, weeks ahead, is another thing. Public roads run through private property all over Australia and access is open provided the motorist does not leave the road. Aboriginal lands should be no different.

Present rules closing, or requiring passes for, the only connecting roads to Western Australia such as the world-famous Gunbarrel Highway through Central Australia from the eastern states are creating a bureaucratic nightmare as well as inconveniencing and often humiliating tourists. It is not as if the issuing of passes is a means of income. They are issued free but both the volume and need to consult with various communities can mean weeks of delay and many frustrating telephone calls. The net result is that tourists are prevented from making spontaneous decisions while travelling and are sometimes ordered off roads.

All this is unnecessary and does not benefit Aboriginal communities. It may satisfy those who hanker for retribution for past injustice but it is destructive and should not be defended by legal sophistry. The hostility that all this is generating not only in the outback but throughout Australia is something which needs urgent attention by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner).

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of the adjournment debate to raise a matter of great seriousness in relation to my electorate, and to tropical fruit growers in particular. The matter is the recent outbreak of the papaya fruit fly, which has been found on a farm between Yarrabah and Gordonvale to the south of Cairns. The papaya fruit fly is a pest which attacks a wide range of commercial and other fruit, including mango, banana and pawpaw—all fruits which are grown commercially in my electorate. Many are exported, so it is a serious issue.

PARA.TAB: It is also a serious issue that coalition members have once again not chosen to be a constructive opposition but have taken the opportunity to score some cheap political points in this matter. TALK.START.PARA: —They seem to think that is funny. A decision has been made to quarantine 80 kilometres around Cairns and sites where the flies have been trapped. TALK.START.PARA: —In Australia right now we have a killer virus which is rivalling the AIDS epidemic and which will have profound, long-term and incalculable effects on our nation. It is estimated currently to affect between 100,000 and 200,000 people in Australia. Based on current trends, it has been estimated that some 7,000 to 9,000 new infections will occur within the next 12 months or, simply put, at the rate of some 25 per day. Of those exposed, 80 per cent will become carriers, 25 per cent will develop a chronic liver disease and five per cent to 10 per cent will die. The new killer in the community is hepatitis C, a virus which is considered to primarily infect the liver of those inflicted. However, a recent brochure, coincidentally written by one of my staff members, really tells a story. The brochure states:

SPEECH.PARA: Hepatitis C is a virus caught by contact with another person.
It is important to note that it is transmitted through an exchange of blood and other bodily fluids. It goes on:
If you have tested positive, or suspect that you may have recently been in contact with, hepatitis C . . . you should be careful that you do not pass it on to others.
It is very important that you:
.do not share needles or injecting equipment;
.have only `safe sex' by using a condom; and
.limit your number of sex partners.

These points very much sound like good advice in the prevention of any transmitted virus, and in particular sounds like information available about AIDS prevention. However, the brochure states that, in relation to hepatitis C, the following steps should also be taken:
.do not share your toothbrush, razors, dental floss—or anything that could come into contact with blood;
.make sure blood stained tissues or other dressings are carefully thrown away;
.cover cuts or wounds with dressing;
.wipe spills of blood or other body fluids with household bleach and cold water; and
.do not donate your blood, body organs, semen or other body tissue.

The brochure states that, although uncommon, the virus can be passed from a mother to her unborn child and that breastfeeding mothers should talk to their doctors for advice. Suffice it to say, this is not a low level virus striking a few, let us say, unlucky victims. This has all the hallmarks of the next major viral epidemic of the decade and will be with us in significant and growing numbers well into the next century. Hepatitis C is not a discrete virus in its own right and information I have suggests that sexually active partners both diagnosed as hepatitis C positive should have only safe sex as `you may have a different type of hepatitis C which you could pass on'.

PARA.TAB: An article in the Australian of 21 October stated that, in the ACT alone, some 100 people were waiting for the only treatment available, that being the drug Interferon, while a possible 1,500 required assessment for treatment. It went on to say that a recent report by the working group of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council indicated that these long lines are due to an overall lack of funding for the management and treatment of hepatitis C.

The federal government made the first specific funding allocation in the last budget. This was only some $3.8 million over the next two years. This amount has been earmarked to cover surveillance, education and prevention. I suggest that this amount is, in fact, ridiculous. This translates to each person receiving assistance worth only $12.67 each. And this funding is to include provision for a national community awareness campaign to be launched—I hate to be cynical in thinking this—prior to the next election campaign and not at a time that suits the immediate needs of sufferers or, more importantly, the overall community, which may be inadvertently exposed to the killer virus.

All in all, the government has been caught napping, particularly the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). The government has been simply too slow to realise the magnitude of this problem and too slow to realise and respond to community needs, as this virus has been known to the medical profession since 1989. It has been negligent in providing grossly insufficient funding—and the queues are getting longer.

The virus is here and the virus is a killer. Let us forget the politics and let us tackle this issue on the grounds of public health. I call upon the minister for health to recognise hepatitis C as a major health crisis facing the community, to take immediate action in this regard and to make a longstanding commitment to provide appropriate funding for all aspects of prevention and treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to pass on my sincere commendation and congratulations to the Queensland Minister for Health, Mr Peter Beattie. In the last few days, Peter Beattie has announced two major hospital renovation and rebuilding programs, both of which will serve the needs of my constituents.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the state Minister for Health announced a major upgrading of the Queen Elizabeth II Hospital, which will lead to significantly improved services to Brisbane's southside residents. Mr Beattie has announced that the hospital will be expanded to provide more surgical, medical, emergency and rehabilitation services. For the first time in this hospital's 15-year history, all six theatres will be used to provide an estimated 3,000 extra operations a year to the residents of the southern suburbs of Brisbane. This will virtually double the number of patients undergoing surgery at the hospital and will also have a substantial impact on waiting lists in the Brisbane south region in specialties such as orthopaedics, urology and gynaecology.

Further, an emergency department will be reopened as part of a regional network of emergency services. It will have a full-time director and will be able to admit or transfer patients according to clinical protocols. There will be a fully staffed, 30-bed medical unit established with up to 3,000 admissions anticipated each year.

The Queen Elizabeth II, or QEII, as we call it in my electorate, is a very important hospital. This is a major improvement in the range of services that will be provided to the residents of the southern suburbs and I am delighted that the minister has seen fit to commit such additional funding to this hospital to enable this upgrading to occur.

The second announcement he has recently made is with regard to a brand new hospital which will be built alongside the existing Princess Alexandra Hospital, which is also on the boundary of my electorate but which serves most of my constituents. There will be $225 million expended to provide a new hospital there. The building program will commence very shortly. The exact site has not yet been worked out because that has to be designed to fit in with the existing facilities, but this will make this complex the major tertiary teaching and research hospital in Brisbane.

I am delighted that the minister has seen fit to allocate such significant amounts of money to health and hospital services in the southern suburbs. This is in sharp contrast, might I say, to the performance of most of the conservative state governments around this country, who have been cutting back on the amount of money they have been expending on the health and hospital services in their states.

The Queensland government has been working very closely with the Commonwealth government and is increasing the amount of money it is allocating to hospitals. These two announcements, serving the needs of my constituents in the southern suburbs of Brisbane, are a very clear indication of the very strong commitment the Labor Party has at both the state and federal levels to health and hospital services and to building up those services.

You might be interested to know that in the 1995-96 financial year the Commonwealth government will be contributing some $862 million to the Queensland hospital sector. That is a significant increase on the previous year, when it was $776 million. Each year for the last five years the Commonwealth has significantly increased in real terms the amount of money it has provided to the Queensland hospital system. In 1992-93, the increase was 4.08 per cent. In 1993-94 we increased funding to the state hospital sector by 9.35 per cent in real terms and in 1994-95 we increased it by 2.33 per cent. In 1995-96, there will be a significant increase, of almost 10 per cent, in the funding to the Queensland hospital system.

The Commonwealth contributes over $2.8 billion a year to looking after the health needs of Queenslanders in the full range of health services that are required. This is a major contribution by the Commonwealth to the welfare of Queenslanders and builds upon the commitment the Queensland state government is making to the health and welfare of its citizens.

In conclusion, I congratulate again the new Minister for Health, Peter Beattie, and promise him that I will work very closely with him to ensure that continuing growth in federal funds occurs and that these new upgrading programs at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital and the PA hospital will proceed. TALK.START.PARA: —The remote outback New South Wales town of White Cliffs is famous for its opals, but tonight I pay tribute to the White Cliffs auxiliary of the Royal Flying Doctor Service for their fundraising efforts for the Royal Flying Doctor Service again this year. It culminated in the annual RFDS dinner dance on Saturday, 14 October. I was honoured to be present at that function along with about 150 other people from White Cliffs and district and the surrounding towns.

PARA.TAB: The major fundraising activity of the auxiliary this year was their sponsored horse ride which they have held each of the last eight years. They take a different route each year and this year the ride was from Wanaaring to Tibooburra over the week 24 September to 30 September. It is a distance of 230 kilometres. I drove it a month or so ago and it is quite a rough track in places.

I had the honour at the dinner dance of presenting the sashes to the successful riders. I would like to read their names out. Claire McCallum of Coonabarabran raised $530. Kate Homfrey of Wilcannia, who also took part in the first ride, raised $1,100. From Wanaaring there was a good contingent—Debbie Eichner, Jo Lindsay, Robin Mann, Barbara Brown and David Threshing. Between them they raised $3,400. From the little town of Tilpa, Colin Middleton and Adelaide Middleton, along with the younger ones, Lisa and Kate Middleton, who travelled in a buggy, raised $3,000. A very fine effort was made by White Cliffs riders Benita Tatt, Kelly Mannion and Maureen Ker, who raised between them $8,593.16. With various sundries, that came to a grand total of $16,773.

I am told that just in the last few days the White Cliffs contingent has had another $500 come in. So over $17,000 will have been raised from this event for the flying doctor service. I particularly pay tribute to Maureen Ker, who has been a tower of strength in recent years with her organisational skills for this ride. She comes from Tarella Station and she works as the sole remote area nurse at White Cliffs.

Some of those riders incidentally were as young as 10 years of age. They had a fine backup team this year of Ben Homfrey, Jan Engis, Adelaide Middleton and Shirley Kot. I think I should also mention the support from Graham and Maxine Wellings at the White Cliffs hotel.

At the dinner dance that night there was a youngster there, only 3 1/2 years old, Shaun Kennewell, who amused the gathering with his guitar playing. He raised over $100 alone on the night. One who did not ride this year but has been in six previous rides was Carol Mengersen. Incidentally, her address is Dugout 3, White Cliffs, if you want to write to her. She has been a great supporter of the event over the years.

The money is put to good use. A few years ago, for example, it paid for the lights on the airstrip so that the King Airs can land at night-time. As well as the horse riding function and the dinner dance, White Cliffs had a family day back in August and also raised over $1,000. So you can see the people of White Cliffs district are very generous indeed.

The royal flying doctor centre is based at Broken Hill. They conduct 35 clinics every year at White Cliffs. They turn up for two weeks out of every three. About 20 to 30 people turn up to each clinic. They have had up to 40 people turning up. In addition to that, they fly two or three people out of the district each month either down to Broken Hill for attention or, if more serious, down to Adelaide.

White Cliffs has a population of only about 80 officially, although there are 200 or 300 there, particularly through the winter months. They live mainly in dugouts. There are only 17 or 18 houses there. From Broken Hill, the flying doctor flies out to Tibooburra, Moomba, Hungerford, Wanaaring, White Cliffs, Louth, Tilpa, Wilcannia, Menindee and Ivanhoe. Most of those towns are in my electorate.

Just over 50 per cent of the income of the flying doctor service comes from donations. The rest comes from the state and Commonwealth government, although I was disappointed the Commonwealth government reduced its contribution by 20 per cent this year. The flying doctor service cannot run without these donations such as are provided by the White Cliffs auxiliary. I think it is appropriate their efforts should be recognised in the Australian parliament. (Time expired)

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Computer System

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his office received complaints from staff in his Department about a computer system installed despite warnings that it did not meet required standards.
(2) Why was the system installed.
(3) Has his office responded to the complaints; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I receive a number of letters from staff which touch on aspects of the Department's computing systems. In particular, I received letters about the impact of the Income Security Applications changes introduced in June, one of, if not the largest, set of changes ever made by DSS. Concerns were expressed that some of the software changes were introduced despite concerns which emerged in testing.

(2) With the June release some software problems were identified late in the process. They were not considered critical at the time but in combination with hardware problems did cause serious operational problems which impacted on staff and customers. Because the system changes are usually interdependent it is often simply not possible to change specific elements. These are dealt with by work arounds introduced at the time of the change or shortly afterwards. Although almost unavoidable this is not a satisfactory situation and every sensible effort is made to avoid problems arising. In the light of recent experience the Department is trialling new ways to avoid the incidence of such problems. However in the final result the changes must proceed to comply with the law and to ensure customers receive their entitlements.
(3) The letters from staff on this matter were answered on my behalf by the Parliamentary Secretary.
